[95]Wikidata
item

Appearance
(BUTTON)
move
to
sidebar
(BUTTON)
hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Look
up
[96]root
or
[97]roots
in
Wiktionary,
the
free
dictionary.

A
[98]root
is
the
part
of
a
plant,
generally
underground,
that
anchors
the
plant
body,
and
absorbs
and
stores
water
and
nutrients.

Root
or
roots
may
also
refer
to:

Art,
entertainment,
and
media

[[99]edit]
*
[100]The
Root
(magazine),
an
online
magazine
focusing
on
African-American
culture
*
The
Roots,
a
location
in
the
video
game
[101]Kya:
Dark
Lineage

Films

[[102]edit]
*
[103]Roots
(film)
(Spanish:
Raíces),
a
1955
Mexican
drama
*
[104]Poor
Relatives,
also
released
as
Roots,
a
2005
Russian
film
*
Roots,
the
English
title
for
the
2019
Tamil
film
[105]Sethum
Aayiram
Pon

Literature
and
stage
plays

Roots),

1954
novel
by
Serbian

Dobrica
Cosic

a
1958

by
Arnold

Saga
of
an
American
Family,

by

about
slavery
in
the
United
States

Computing

[[157]edit]
*
[158]/root,
the
Unix
superuser's
home
directory
in
the
Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard
*
[159]ROOT,
an
object-oriented
multipurpose
data
analysis
package
*
root,
a
name
for
the
[160]superuser
account
in
some
operating
systems
*
[161]Root
directory,
the
first
or
top-most
directory
in
a
hierarchy
*
[162]Root
node,
the
node
in
a
tree
data
structure
from
which
every
other
node
is
accessible
*
[163]ROOTS
(software),
a
series
of
genealogy
programs

Mathematics

[[164]edit]
*
[165]nth
root
of
a
number
+
[166]Root
of
unity,
a
complex
number
which
is
an
nth
root
of
one
*
[167]Root
of
an
equation,
a
solution
of
the
equation
*
[168]Root
of
a
function,
more
meaningfully
called
zero
of
a
function,
an
argument
for
which
the
function
evaluates
to
zero
*
[169]Digital
root,
the
sum
of
a
number's
digits
*
Any
of
the
elements
of
a
[170]root
system
of
vectors
*
One
designated
vertex
of
a
[171]rooted
tree
in
graph
theory
*
The
root
or
[172]base
of
a
number
system

Surname
list

page
lists
people
with
the
[118]surname
Root.
If
an
[119]internal
link
intending
to
refer
to
a
specific
person
led
you
to
this
page,
you
may
wish
to
change
that
[120]link
by
adding
the
person's
[121]given
name(s)
to
the
link.

*
[72]Wikidata
item

Appearance
(BUTTON)
move
to
sidebar
(BUTTON)
hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Type
of
tissue
at
the
tip
of
a
plant
root
[73][220px-Root-tip-tag.png]
Root
tip
magnified
100×.
1.
Meristem
2.
Columellae
([74]statocytes
with
statolithes)
3.
Lateral
part
of
the
tip
4.
Dead
cells
5.
Elongation
zone

The
root
cap
is
a
type
of
tissue
at
the
tip
of
a
plant
[75]root.^[76][1]
It
is
also
called
[77]calyptra.
Root
caps
contain
[78]statocytes
which
are
involved
in
[79]gravity
perception
in
plants.^[80][1]
If
the
cap
is
carefully
removed
the
root
will
grow
randomly.
The
root
cap
protects
the
[81]growing
tip
in
plants.^[82][1]
It
secretes
[83]mucilage
to
ease
the
movement
of
the
root
through
soil,^[84][1]
and
may
also
be
involved
in
communication
with
the
soil
microbiota.^[85][1]

The
purpose
of
the
root
cap
is
to
enable
downward
growth
of
the
root,
with
the
root
cap
covering
the
sensitive
tissue
in
the
root.^[86][2]
Thanks
to
the
presence
of
[87]statocytes,
the
root
cap
enables
geoperception
or
gravitropism.
This
allows
the
plant
to
grow
downwards
(with
gravity)
or
upwards
(against
gravity).^[88][3]

The
root
cap
is
absent
in
some
parasitic
plants^[89][4]^:
138
and
some
[90]aquatic
plants,
in
which
a
sac-like
structure
called
the
root
pocket
may
form
instead.^[91][5]^:
2-76

Root
directory

]

[76]Printable

In
other
projects
*
[77]Wikidata
item

Appearance
(BUTTON)
move
to
sidebar
(BUTTON)
hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
First
or
top-most
directory
in
a
hierarchy
For
other
uses,
see
[78]Root
(disambiguation).
[79][220px-OpenIndiana_2015_Console_LS.png]
View
of
the
root
directory
in
the
[80]OpenIndiana
operating
system

In
a
[81]computer
[82]file
system,
and
primarily
used
in
the
[83]Unix
and
[84]Unix-like
[85]operating
systems,
the
root
directory
is
the
first
or
top-most
[86]directory
in
a
hierarchy.^[87][1]
It
can
be
likened
to
the
trunk
of
a
[88]tree,
as
the
starting
point
where
all
branches
originate
from.
The
root
file
system
is
the
file
system
contained
on
the
same
[89]disk
partition
on
which
the
root
directory
is
located;
it
is
the
filesystem
on
top
of
which
all
other
file
systems
are
[90]mounted
as
the
system
boots
up.^[91][2]

Unix-like
systems

[[92]edit]

Unix
abstracts
the
nature
of
this
tree
hierarchy
entirely
and
in
Unix
and
Unix-like
systems
the
root
directory
is
denoted
by
the
/
(slash)
sign.
Though
the
root
directory
is
conventionally
referred
to
as
/,
the
directory
entry
itself
has
no
name
-
its
path
is
the
"empty"
part
before
the
initial
directory
separator
character
(/).
All
file
system
entries,
including
mounted
file
systems
are
"branches"
of
this
root.^[93][1]

chroot

[[94]edit]

In
UNIX-like
operating
systems,
each
[95]process
has
its
own
idea
of
what
the
root
directory
is.
For
most
processes
this
is
the
same
as
the
system's
actual
root
directory,
but
it
can
be
changed
by
calling
the
[96]chroot
[97]system
call.
This
is
typically
done
to
create
a
secluded
environment
to
run
software
that
requires
legacy
libraries
and
sometimes
to
simplify
software
installation
and
debugging.
Chroot
is
not
meant
to
be
used
for
enhanced
security
as
the
processes
inside
can
break
out.^[98][3]

Super-root

[[99]edit]
See
also:
[100]Newcastle
Connection

Some
Unix
systems
support
a
directory
below
the
root
directory.
Normally,
"/.."
points
back
to
the
same
[101]inode
as
"/",
however,
under
[102]MUNIX
[[103]de],
this
can
be
changed
to
point
to
a
super-root
directory,
where
remote
trees
can
be
mounted.^[104][4]^[105][5]
If,
for
example,
two
workstations
"pcs2a"
and
"pcs2b"
were
connected
via
"connectnodes"
and
"uunite"
startup
script,
"/../pcs2b"
could
be
used
to
access
the
root
directory
of
"pcs2b"
from
"pcs2a".

DOS/Windows
systems

[[106]edit]

Under
[107]DOS,
[108]OS/2,
and
[109]Microsoft
Windows,
each
partition
has
a
drive
letter
assignment
(e.g.
the
C
partition
is
labeled
C:\)
and
there
is
no
public
root
directory
on
it.

Related
uses

[[110]edit]

On
many
[111]Unixes,
there
is
also
a
directory
named
/root
(pronounced
"slash
root").^[112][6]
This
is
the
[113]home
directory
of
the
'root'
[114]superuser.
On
many
[115]Mac
and
[116]iOS
systems
this
superuser
home
directory
is
/var/root.^[117][6]

A
[118]home
page's
[119]URL
usually
points
to
the
root
of
the
respective
[120]website's
[121]domain
name.

See
also

[[122]edit]
*
[123]Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard
(FHS)
*
[124]Parent
directory
*
[125]Working
directory

[8]Home[9]Bits
and
BytesRoot
Directory
Definition

Root
Directory

The
root
directory,
or
root
folder,
is
the
top-level
[10]directory
of
a
[11]file
system.
The
directory
structure
can
be
visually
represented
as
an
upside-down
tree,
so
the
term
"[12]root"
represents
the
top
level.
All
other
directories
within
a
[13]volume
are
"branches"
or
[14]subdirectories
of
the
root
directory.

While
all
file
systems
have
a
root
directory,
it
may
be
labeled
differently
depending
on
the
[15]operating
system.
For
example,
in
[16]Windows,
the
[17]default
root
directory
is
C:\.
On
[18]Unix
systems
and
in
[19]OS
X,
the
root
directory
is
typically
labeled
simply
/
(a
single
forward
slash).
As
you
move
up
directories
within
a
file
system,
you
will
eventually
reach
the
root
directory.

Website
Root
Directory

The
root
directory
of
a
[20]website
is
not
the
top-level
directory
of
the
volume,
but
rather
the
top-level
directory
of
the
website
folder.
On
an
[21]Apache
server,
for
example,
the
name
of
the
root
directory
is
public_html
and
is
located
within
primary
user
folder
for
the
website.
Therefore,
the
root
folder
of
a
website
can
be
accessed
using
a
single
forward
slash.
For
example,
a
[22]link
to
a
file
called
home.html
within
the
root
directory
of
a
website
can
be
accessed
using
the
reference
"/home.html."
Updated
August
5,
2015
by
[23]Per
C.
(BUTTON)
APA
(BUTTON)
MLA
(BUTTON)
Chicago
(BUTTON)

The
Tech
Terms
Computer
Dictionary

The
definition
of
Root
Directory
on
this
page
is
an
original
definition
written
by
the
[39]TechTerms.com
team.
If
you
would
like
to
reference
this
page
or
cite
this
definition,
please
use
the
green
citation
links
above.

The
goal
of
TechTerms.com
is
to
explain
computer
terminology
in
a
way
that
is
easy
to
understand.
We
strive
for
simplicity
and
accuracy
with
every
definition
we
publish.
If
you
have
feedback
about
this
definition
or
would
like
to
suggest
a
new
technical
term,
please
[40]contact
us.

[1]LINFO

Root
Filesystem
Definition

The
root
filesystem
is
the
[2]filesystem
that
is
contained
on
the
same
[3]partition
on
which
the
[4]root
directory
is
located,
and
it
is
the
filesystem
on
which
all
the
other
filesystems
are
mounted
(i.e.,
logically
attached
to
the
system)
as
the
system
is
[5]booted
up
(i.e.,
started
up).

A
partition
is
a
logically
independent
section
of
a
hard
disk
drive
(HDD).
A
filesystem
is
a
hierarchy
of
directories
(also
referred
to
as
a
[6]directory
tree)
that
is
used
to
organize
files
on
a
computer
system.
On
[7]Linux
and
and
other
[8]Unix-like
[9]operating
systems,
the
directories
start
with
the
root
directory,
which
contains
a
series
of
subdirectories,
each
of
which,
in
turn,
contains
further
subdirectories,
etc.
A
variant
of
this
definition
is
the
part
of
the
entire
hierarchy
of
directories
(i.e.,
of
the
directory
tree)
that
is
located
on
a
single
partition
or
disk.

The
exact
contents
of
the
root
filesystem
will
vary
according
to
the
computer,
but
they
will
include
the
files
that
are
necessary
for
booting
the
system
and
for
bringing
it
up
to
such
a
state
that
the
other
filesystems
can
be
mounted
as
well
as
tools
for
fixing
a
broken
system
and
for
recovering
lost
files
from
backups.
The
contents
will
include
the
root
directory
together
with
a
minimal
set
of
subdirectories
and
files
including
/boot,
/dev,
/etc,
[10]/bin,
[11]/sbin
and
sometimes
/tmp
(for
temporary
files).

Only
the
root
filesystem
is
available
when
a
system
is
brought
up
in
single
user
mode.
Single
user
mode
is
a
way
of
booting
a
damaged
system
that
has
very
limited
capabilities
so
that
repairs
can
be
made
to
it.
After
repairs
have
been
completed,
the
other
filesystems
that
are
located
on
different
partitions
or
on
different
media
can
then
be
mounted
on
(i.e.,
attached
to)
the
root
filesystem
in
order
to
restore
full
system
functionality.
The
directories
on
which
they
are
mounted
are
called
[12]mount
points.

The
root
filesystem
should
generally
be
small,
because
it
contains
critical
files
and
a
small,
infrequently
modified
filesystem
has
a
better
chance
of
not
becoming
corrupted.
A
corrupted
root
filesystem
will
generally
mean
that
the
system
becomes
unbootable
(i.e.,
unstartable)
from
the
HDD,
and
must
be
booted
by
special
means
(e.g.,
from
a
boot
floppy).

A
filesystem
can
be
mounted
anywhere
in
the
directory
tree;
it
does
not
necessarily
need
to
be
mounted
on
the
root
filesystem.
For
example,
it
is
possible
(and
very
common)
to
have
one
filesystem
mounted
at
a
mount
point
on
the
root
filesystem,
and
another
filesystem
mounted
at
a
mount
point
contained
in
that
filesystem.

Created
April
18,
2006.
Copyright
©
2006
The
Linux
Information
Project.
All
Rights
Reserved.

Appearance
(BUTTON)
move
to
sidebar
(BUTTON)
hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Number
that
has
an
integer
power
equal
to
1
This
article
needs
additional
citations
for
[99]verification.
Please
help
[100]improve
this
article
by
[101]adding
citations
to
reliable
sources.
Unsourced
material
may
be
challenged
and
removed.
Find
sources:
[102]"Root
of
unity"
-
[103]news
·
[104]newspapers
·
[105]books
·
[106]scholar
·
[107]JSTOR
(April
2012)
([108]Learn
how
and
when
to
remove
this
message)

[109][220px-One5Root.svg.png]
The
5th
roots
of
unity
(blue
points)
in
the
[110]complex
plane

In
[111]mathematics,
a
root
of
unity,
occasionally
called
a
[112]de
Moivre
number,
is
any
[113]complex
number
that
yields
1
when
[114]raised
to
some
positive
[115]integer
power
n.
Roots
of
unity
are
used
in
many
branches
of
mathematics,
and
are
especially
important
in
[116]number
theory,
the
theory
of
[117]group
characters,
and
the
[118]discrete
Fourier
transform.

Roots
of
unity
can
be
defined
in
any
[119]field.
If
the
[120]characteristic
of
the
field
is
zero,
the
roots
are
complex
numbers
that
are
also
[121]algebraic
integers.
For
fields
with
a
positive
characteristic,
the
roots
belong
to
a
[122]finite
field,
and,
[123]conversely,
every
nonzero
element
of
a
finite
field
is
a
root
of
unity.
Any
[124]algebraically
closed
field
contains
exactly
n
nth
roots
of
unity,
except
when
n
is
a
multiple
of
the
(positive)
characteristic
of
the
field.

General
definition

[[125]edit]
[126][220px-Visualisation_complex_number_roots.svg.png]
Geometric
representation
of
the
2nd
to
6th
root
of
a
general
complex
number
in
polar
form.
For
the
nth
root
of
unity,
set
r
=
1
and
f
=
0.
The
principal
root
is
in
black.

An
nth
root
of
unity,
where
n
is
a
positive
integer,
is
a
number
z
satisfying
the
[127]equation^[128][1]^[129][2]
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{n}=1.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{n}=1.}
Unless
otherwise
specified,
the
roots
of
unity
may
be
taken
to
be
[130]complex
numbers
(including
the
number
1,
and
the
number
-1
if
n
is
[131]even,
which
are
complex
with
a
zero
[132]imaginary
part),
and
in
this
case,
the
nth
roots
of
unity
are^[133][3]
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>exp</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
<mspace
width="2em"
/>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\exp
\left({\frac
{2k\pi
i}{n}}\right)=\cos
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}},\qquad
k=0,1,\dots
,n-1.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\exp
\left({\frac
{2k\pi
i}{n}}\right)=\cos
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}},\qquad
k=0,1,\dots
,n-1.}

However,
the
defining
equation
of
roots
of
unity
is
meaningful
over
any
[134]field
(and
even
over
any
[135]ring)
F,
and
this
allows
considering
roots
of
unity
in
F.
Whichever
is
the
field
F,
the
roots
of
unity
in
F
are
either
complex
numbers,
if
the
[136]characteristic
of
F
is
0,
or,
otherwise,
belong
to
a
[137]finite
field.
Conversely,
every
nonzero
element
in
a
finite
field
is
a
root
of
unity
in
that
field.
See
[138]Root
of
unity
modulo
n
and
[139]Finite
field
for
further
details.

An
nth
root
of
unity
is
said
to
be
primitive
if
it
is
not
an
mth
root
of
unity
for
some
smaller
m,
that
is
if^[140][4]^[141][5]

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>and</mtext>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>m</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>!=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>
for
</mtext>
</mrow>
<mi>m</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mn>3</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{n}=1\quad
{\text{and}}\quad
z^{m}\neq
1{\text{
for
}}m=1,2,3,\ldots
,n-1.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{n}=1\quad
{\text{and}}\quad
z^{m}\neq
1{\text{
for
}}m=1,2,3,\ldots
,n-1.}

If
n
is
a
[142]prime
number,
then
all
nth
roots
of
unity,
except
1,
are
primitive.^[143][6]

In
the
above
formula
in
terms
of
exponential
and
trigonometric
functions,
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity
are
those
for
which
k
and
n
are
[144]coprime
integers.

Subsequent
sections
of
this
article
will
comply
with
complex
roots
of
unity.
For
the
case
of
roots
of
unity
in
fields
of
nonzero
characteristic,
see
[145]Finite
field
§
Roots
of
unity.
For
the
case
of
roots
of
unity
in
rings
of
[146]modular
integers,
see
[147]Root
of
unity
modulo
n.

Elementary
properties

[[148]edit]

Every
nth
root
of
unity
z
is
a
primitive
ath
root
of
unity
for
some
a
<=
n,
which
is
the
smallest
positive
integer
such
that
z^a
=
1.

Any
integer
power
of
an
nth
root
of
unity
is
also
an
nth
root
of
unity,^[149][7]
as

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mn>1</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
(z^{k})^{n}=z^{kn}=(z^{n})^{k}=1^{k}=1.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
(z^{k})^{n}=z^{kn}=(z^{n})^{k}=1^{k}=1.}

This
is
also
true
for
negative
exponents.
In
particular,
the
[150]reciprocal
of
an
nth
root
of
unity
is
its
[151]complex
conjugate,
and
is
also
an
nth
root
of
unity:^[152][8]

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mn>1</mn>
<mi>z</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mover>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">¯</mo>
</mover>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{1}{z}}=z^{-1}=z^{n-1}={\bar
{z}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{1}{z}}=z^{-1}=z^{n-1}={\bar
{z}}.}

If
z
is
an
nth
root
of
unity
and
a
=3
b
(mod
n)
then
z^a
=
z^b.
Indeed,
by
the
definition
of
[153]congruence
modulo
n,
a
=
b
+
kn
for
some
integer
k,
and
hence

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>a</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<msup>
<mn>1</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b+kn}=z^{b}z^{kn}=z^{b}(z^{n})^{k}=z^{b}1^{k}=z^{b}.}</
annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b+kn}=z^{b}z^{kn}=z^{b}(z^{n})^{k}=z^{b}1^{k}=z^{b}.}

Therefore,
given
a
power
z^a
of
z,
one
has
z^a
=
z^r,
where
0
<=
r
<
n
is
the
remainder
of
the
[154]Euclidean
division
of
a
by
n.

Let
z
be
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity.
Then
the
powers
z,
z^2,
...,
z^n-1,
z^n
=
z^0
=
1
are
nth
roots
of
unity
and
are
all
distinct.
(If
z^a
=
z^b
where
1
<=
a
<
b
<=
n,
then
z^b-a
=
1,
which
would
imply
that
z
would
not
be
primitive.)
This
implies
that
z,
z^2,
...,
z^n-1,
z^n
=
z^0
=
1
are
all
of
the
nth
roots
of
unity,
since
an
nth-[155]degree
[156]polynomial
equation
over
a
field
(in
this
case
the
field
of
complex
numbers)
has
at
most
n
solutions.

From
the
preceding,
it
follows
that,
if
z
is
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity,
then
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>a</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b}}
[157]if
and
only
if
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>=3</mo>
<mi>b</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>mod</mi>
<mspace
width="0.333em"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
a\equiv
b{\pmod
{n}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
a\equiv
b{\pmod
{n}}.}
If
z
is
not
primitive
then
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>=3</mo>
<mi>b</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>mod</mi>
<mspace
width="0.333em"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
a\equiv
b{\pmod
{n}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
a\equiv
b{\pmod
{n}}}
implies
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>a</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>b</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{a}=z^{b},}
but
the
converse
may
be
false,
as
shown
by
the
following
example.
If
n
=
4,
a
non-primitive
nth
root
of
unity
is
z
=
-1,
and
one
has
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>4</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{2}=z^{4}=1}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{2}=z^{4}=1}
,
although
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>2</mn>
<mo>
!=3
</mo>
<mn>4</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>mod</mi>
<mspace
width="0.333em"
/>
<mn>4</mn>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
2\not
\equiv
4{\pmod
{4}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
2\not
\equiv
4{\pmod
{4}}.}

Let
z
be
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity.
A
power
w
=
z^k
of
z
is
a
primitive
ath
root
of
unity
for

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>n</mi>
<mrow>
<mo
movablelimits="true"
form="prefix">gcd</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
a={\frac
{n}{\gcd(k,n)}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
a={\frac
{n}{\gcd(k,n)}},}

where
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo
movablelimits="true"
form="prefix">gcd</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\gcd(k,n)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\gcd(k,n)}
is
the
[158]greatest
common
divisor
of
n
and
k.
This
results
from
the
fact
that
ka
is
the
smallest
multiple
of
k
that
is
also
a
multiple
of
n.
In
other
words,
ka
is
the
[159]least
common
multiple
of
k
and
n.
Thus

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mi>lcm</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
<mi>k</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo
movablelimits="true"
form="prefix">gcd</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>n</mi>
<mrow>
<mo
movablelimits="true"
form="prefix">gcd</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
a={\frac
{\operatorname
{lcm}
(k,n)}{k}}={\frac
{kn}{k\gcd(k,n)}}={\frac
{n}{\gcd(k,n)}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
a={\frac
{\operatorname
{lcm}
(k,n)}{k}}={\frac
{kn}{k\gcd(k,n)}}={\frac
{n}{\gcd(k,n)}}.}

Thus,
if
k
and
n
are
[160]coprime,
z^k
is
also
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity,
and
therefore
there
are
f(n)
distinct
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity
(where
f
is
[161]Euler's
totient
function).
This
implies
that
if
n
is
a
prime
number,
all
the
roots
except
+1
are
primitive.

In
other
words,
if
R(n)
is
the
set
of
all
nth
roots
of
unity
and
P(n)
is
the
set
of
primitive
ones,
R(n)
is
a
[162]disjoint
union
of
the
P(n):

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi
mathvariant="normal">R</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>&#x22C3;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mi
mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>d</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{R}
(n)=\bigcup
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{P}
(d),}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{R}
(n)=\bigcup
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{P}
(d),}

where
the
notation
means
that
d
goes
through
all
the
positive
[163]divisors
of
n,
including
1
and
n.

Since
the
[164]cardinality
of
R(n)
is
n,
and
that
of
P(n)
is
f(n),
this
demonstrates
the
classical
formula

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mi>f</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>d</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\varphi
(d)=n.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\varphi
(d)=n.}

Group
properties

[[165]edit]

Group
of
all
roots
of
unity

[[166]edit]

The
product
and
the
[167]multiplicative
inverse
of
two
roots
of
unity
are
also
roots
of
unity.
In
fact,
if
x^m
=
1
and
y^n
=
1,
then
(x^-1)^m
=
1,
and
(xy)^k
=
1,
where
k
is
the
[168]least
common
multiple
of
m
and
n.

Therefore,
the
roots
of
unity
form
an
[169]abelian
group
under
multiplication.
This
[170]group
is
the
[171]torsion
subgroup
of
the
[172]circle
group.

Group
of
nth
roots
of
unity

[[173]edit]

For
an
integer
n,
the
product
and
the
multiplicative
inverse
of
two
nth
roots
of
unity
are
also
nth
roots
of
unity.
Therefore,
the
nth
roots
of
unity
form
an
abelian
group
under
multiplication.

Given
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity
w,
the
other
nth
roots
are
powers
of
w.
This
means
that
the
group
of
the
nth
roots
of
unity
is
a
[174]cyclic
group.
It
is
worth
remarking
that
the
term
of
cyclic
group
originated
from
the
fact
that
this
group
is
a
[175]subgroup
of
the
[176]circle
group.

Galois
group
of
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity

[[177]edit]

Let
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
be
the
[178]field
extension
of
the
[179]rational
numbers
generated
over
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
}
by
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity
w.
As
every
nth
root
of
unity
is
a
power
of
w,
the
[180]field
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi

</mrow>
<mo

<mi>w</mi>
<mo

</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation

\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
contains
all
nth
roots
of
unity,
and
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
is
a
[181]Galois
extension
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
.}

If
k
is
an
integer,
w^k
is
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity
if
and
only
if
k
and
n
are
[182]coprime.
In
this
case,
the
map

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">|-></mo>
<msup>
<mi>w</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\omega
\mapsto
\omega
^{k}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\omega
\mapsto
\omega
^{k}}

induces
an
[183]automorphism
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
,
which
maps
every
nth
root
of
unity
to
its
kth
power.
Every
automorphism
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
is
obtained
in
this
way,
and
these
automorphisms
form
the
[184]Galois
group
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
)}
over
the
field
of
the
rationals.

The
rules
of
exponentiation
imply
that
the
[185]composition
of
two
such
automorphisms
is
obtained
by
multiplying
the
exponents.
It
follows
that
the
map

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">|-></mo>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">|-></mo>
<msup>
<mi>w</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
k\mapsto
\left(\omega
\mapsto
\omega
^{k}\right)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
k\mapsto
\left(\omega
\mapsto
\omega
^{k}\right)}

defines
a
[186]group
isomorphism
between
the
[187]units
of
the
ring
of
[188]integers
modulo
n
and
the
Galois
group
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi
mathvariant="double-struck">Q</mi>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>w</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\mathbb
{Q}
(\omega
).}

This
shows
that
this
Galois
group
is
[189]abelian,
and
implies
thus
that
the
primitive
roots
of
unity
may
be
expressed
in
terms
of
[190]radicals.

Galois
group
of
the
real
part
of
the
primitive
roots
of
unity

[[191]edit]
Main
article:
[192]Minimal
polynomial
of
2cos(2pi/n)

The
real
part
of
the
primitive
roots
of
unity
are
related
to
one
another
as
roots
of
the
[193]minimal
polynomial
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>/</mo>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
2\cos(2\pi
/n).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
2\cos(2\pi
/n).}
The
roots
of
the
minimal
polynomial
are
just
twice
the
real
part;
these
roots
form
a
cyclic
Galois
group.

Trigonometric
expression

[[194]edit]
[195][220px-3rd_roots_of_unity_correction.svg.png]
The
cube
roots
of
unity

[196]De
Moivre's
formula,
which
is
valid
for
all
[197]real
x
and
integers
n,
is

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
x+i\sin
x\right)^{n}=\cos
nx+i\sin
nx.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
x+i\sin
x\right)^{n}=\cos
nx+i\sin
nx.}

Setting
x
=
&#8288;2p/n&#8288;
gives
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity
-
one
gets

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mspace
width="negativethinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}\right)^{\!n}=\cos
2\pi
+i\sin
2\pi
=1,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}\right)^{\!n}=\cos
2\pi
+i\sin
2\pi
=1,}

but

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mspace
width="negativethinmathspace"
/>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>!=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}\right)^{\!k}=\cos
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}\neq
1}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\left(\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}\right)^{\!k}=\cos
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2k\pi
}{n}}\neq
1}

for
k
=
1,
2,
...,
n
-
1.
In
other
words,

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}}

is
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity.

This
formula
shows
that
in
the
[198]complex
plane
the
nth
roots
of
unity
are
at
the
vertices
of
a
[199]regular
n-sided
polygon
inscribed
in
the
[200]unit
circle,
with
one
vertex
at
1
(see
the
plots
for
n
=
3
and
n
=
5
on
the
right).
This
geometric
fact
accounts
for
the
term
"cyclotomic"
in
such
phrases
as
[201]cyclotomic
field
and
[202]cyclotomic
polynomial;
it
is
from
the
Greek
roots
"[203]cyclo"
(circle)
plus
"[204]tomos"
(cut,
divide).

[205]Euler's
formula

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>x</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
e^{ix}=\cos
x+i\sin
x,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
e^{ix}=\cos
x+i\sin
x,}

which
is
valid
for
all
real
x,
can
be
used
to
put
the
formula
for
the
nth
roots
of
unity
into
the
form

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>,</mo>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo><=</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo><</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
e^{2\pi
i{\frac
{k}{n}}},\quad
0\leq
k<n.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
e^{2\pi
i{\frac
{k}{n}}},\quad
0\leq
k<n.}

It
follows
from
the
discussion
in
the
previous
section
that
this
is
a
primitive
nth-root
if
and
only
if
the
fraction
&#8288;k/n&#8288;
is
in
lowest
terms;
that
is,
that
k
and
n
are
coprime.
An
[206]irrational
number
that
can
be
expressed
as
the
[207]real
part
of
the
root
of
unity;
that
is,
as
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>k</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>/</mo>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\cos(2\pi
k/n)}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\cos(2\pi
k/n)}
,
is
called
a
[208]trigonometric
number.

Algebraic
expression

[[209]edit]

The
nth
roots
of
unity
are,
by
definition,
the
[210]roots
of
the
[211]polynomial
x^n
-
1,
and
are
thus
[212]algebraic
numbers.
As
this
polynomial
is
not
[213]irreducible
(except
for
n
=
1),
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity
are
roots
of
an
irreducible
polynomial
(over
the
integers)
of
lower
degree,
called
the
nth
[214]cyclotomic
polynomial,
and
often
denoted
F[n].
The
degree
of
F[n]
is
given
by
[215]Euler's
totient
function,
which
counts
(among
other
things)
the
number
of
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity.^[216][9]
The
roots
of
F[n]
are
exactly
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity.

[217]Galois
theory
can
be
used
to
show
that
the
cyclotomic
polynomials
may
be
conveniently
solved
in
terms
of
radicals.
(The
trivial
form
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mroot>
<mn>1</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</mroot>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{1}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{1}}}
is
not
convenient,
because
it
contains
non-primitive
roots,
such
as
1,
which
are
not
roots
of
the
cyclotomic
polynomial,
and
because
it
does
not
give
the
real
and
imaginary
parts
separately.)
This
means
that,
for
each
positive
integer
n,
there
exists
an
expression
built
from
integers
by
root
extractions,
additions,
subtractions,
multiplications,
and
divisions
(and
nothing
else),
such
that
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity
are
exactly
the
set
of
values
that
can
be
obtained
by
choosing
values
for
the
root
extractions
(k
possible
values
for
a
kth
root).
(For
more
details
see
[218]§
Cyclotomic
fields,
below.)

Gauss
[219]proved
that
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity
can
be
expressed
using
only
[220]square
roots,
addition,
subtraction,
multiplication
and
division
if
and
only
if
it
is
possible
to
[221]construct
with
compass
and
straightedge
the
[222]regular
n-gon.
This
is
the
case
[223]if
and
only
if
n
is
either
a
[224]power
of
two
or
the
product
of
a
power
of
two
and
[225]Fermat
primes
that
are
all
different.

If
z
is
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity,
the
same
is
true
for
1/z,
and
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>r</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mn>1</mn>
<mi>z</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
r=z+{\frac
{1}{z}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
r=z+{\frac
{1}{z}}}
is
twice
the
real
part
of
z.
In
other
words,
F[n]
is
a
[226]reciprocal
polynomial,
the
polynomial
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>R</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
R_{n}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
R_{n}}
that
has
r
as
a
root
may
be
deduced
from
F[n]
by
the
standard
manipulation
on
reciprocal
polynomials,
and
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity
may
be
deduced
from
the
roots
of
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>R</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
R_{n}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
R_{n}}
by
solving
the
[227]quadratic
equation
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mi>r</mi>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{2}-rz+1=0.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{2}-rz+1=0.}
That
is,
the
real
part
of
the
primitive
root
is
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>r</mi>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{r}{2}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{r}{2}},}
and
its
imaginary
part
is
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo>±</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>-</mo>
<msup>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>r</mi>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\pm
i{\sqrt
{1-\left({\frac
{r}{2}}\right)^{2}}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\pm
i{\sqrt
{1-\left({\frac
{r}{2}}\right)^{2}}}.}

The
polynomial
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>R</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
R_{n}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
R_{n}}
is
an
irreducible
polynomial
whose
roots
are
all
real.
Its
degree
is
a
power
of
two,
if
and
only
if
n
is
a
product
of
a
power
of
two
by
a
product
(possibly
[228]empty)
of
distinct
Fermat
primes,
and
the
regular
n-gon
is
constructible
with
compass
and
straightedge.
Otherwise,
it
is
solvable
in
radicals,
but
one
are
in
the
[229]casus
irreducibilis,
that
is,
every
expression
of
the
roots
in
terms
of
radicals
involves
nonreal
radicals.

Explicit
expressions
in
low
degrees

[[230]edit]
*
For
n
=
1,
the
cyclotomic
polynomial
is
F[1](x)
=
x
-
1
Therefore,
the
only
primitive
first
root
of
unity
is
1,
which
is
a
non-primitive
nth
root
of
unity
for
every
n
>
1.
*
As
F[2](x)
=
x
+
1,
the
only
primitive
second
(square)
root
of
unity
is
-1,
which
is
also
a
non-primitive
nth
root
of
unity
for
every
even
n
>
2.
With
the
preceding
case,
this
completes
the
list
of
[231]real
roots
of
unity.
*
As
F[3](x)
=
x^2
+
x
+
1,
the
primitive
third
([232]cube)
roots
of
unity,
which
are
the
roots
of
this
[233]quadratic
polynomial,
are
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>3</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
<mtext>
</mtext>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>-</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>3</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{-1+i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}},\
{\frac
{-1-i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{-1+i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}},\
{\frac
{-1-i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}}.}
*
As
F[4](x)
=
x^2
+
1,
the
two
primitive
fourth
roots
of
unity
are
i
and
-i.
*
As
F[5](x)
=
x^4
+
x^3
+
x^2
+
x
+
1,
the
four
primitive
fifth
roots
of
unity
are
the
roots
of
this
[234]quartic
polynomial,
which
may
be
explicitly
solved
in
terms
of
radicals,
giving
the
roots
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>5</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mn>4</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>±</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<msqrt>
<mn>10</mn>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>5</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</msqrt>
<mn>4</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\varepsilon
{\sqrt
{5}}-1}{4}}\pm
i{\frac
{\sqrt
{10+2\varepsilon
{\sqrt
{5}}}}{4}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\varepsilon
{\sqrt
{5}}-1}{4}}\pm
i{\frac
{\sqrt
{10+2\varepsilon
{\sqrt
{5}}}}{4}},}
where
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>e</mi>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\varepsilon
}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\varepsilon
}
may
take
the
two
values
1
and
-1
(the
same
value
in
the
two
occurrences).
*
As
F[6](x)
=
x^2
-
x
+
1,
there
are
two
primitive
sixth
roots
of
unity,
which
are
the
negatives
(and
also
the
square
roots)
of
the
two
primitive
cube
roots:
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>3</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
<mtext>
</mtext>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>-</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>3</mn>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{1+i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}},\
{\frac
{1-i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{1+i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}},\
{\frac
{1-i{\sqrt
{3}}}{2}}.}
*
As
7
is
not
a
Fermat
prime,
the
seventh
roots
of
unity
are
the
first
that
require
[235]cube
roots.
There
are
6
primitive
seventh
roots
of
unity,
which
are
pairwise
[236]complex
conjugate.
The
sum
of
a
root
and
its
conjugate
is
twice
its
real
part.
These
three
sums
are
the
three
real
roots
of
the
cubic
polynomial
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>r</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>3</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>+</mo>
<msup>
<mi>r</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>r</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
r^{3}+r^{2}-2r-1,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
r^{3}+r^{2}-2r-1,}
and
the
primitive
seventh
roots
of
unity
are
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>r</mi>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>±</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>-</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<msup>
<mi>r</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mn>4</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{r}{2}}\pm
i{\sqrt
{1-{\frac
{r^{2}}{4}}}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{r}{2}}\pm
i{\sqrt
{1-{\frac
{r^{2}}{4}}}},}
where
r
runs
over
the
roots
of
the
above
polynomial.
As
for
every
cubic
polynomial,
these
roots
may
be
expressed
in
terms
of
square
and
cube
roots.
However,
as
these
three
roots
are
all
real,
this
is
[237]casus
irreducibilis,
and
any
such
expression
involves
non-real
cube
roots.
*
As
F[8](x)
=
x^4
+
1,
the
four
primitive
eighth
roots
of
unity
are
the
square
roots
of
the
primitive
fourth
roots,
±
i.
They
are
thus
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo>±</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<msqrt>
<mn>2</mn>
</msqrt>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>±</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<msqrt>
<mn>2</mn>
</msqrt>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\pm
{\frac
{\sqrt
{2}}{2}}\pm
i{\frac
{\sqrt
{2}}{2}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\pm
{\frac
{\sqrt
{2}}{2}}\pm
i{\frac
{\sqrt
{2}}{2}}.}
*
See
[238]Heptadecagon
for
the
real
part
of
a
17th
root
of
unity.

Periodicity

[[239]edit]

If
z
is
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity,
then
the
sequence
of
powers

...
,
z^-1,
z^0,
z^1,
...

is
n-periodic
(because
z^
j
+
n
=
z^
jz^
n
=
z^
j
for
all
values
of
j),
and
the
n
sequences
of
powers

s[k]:
...
,
z^
k
·
(-1),
z^
k
·
0,
z^
k
·
1,
...

for
k
=
1,
...
,
n
are
all
n-periodic
(because
z^
k
·
(j
+
n)
=
z^
k
·
j).
Furthermore,
the
set
{s[1],
...
,
s[n]}
of
these
sequences
is
a
[240]basis
of
the
[241]linear
space
of
all
n-periodic
sequences.
This
means
that
any
n-periodic
sequence
of
complex
numbers

...
,
x[-1]
,
x[0]
,
x[1],
...

can
be
expressed
as
a
[242]linear
combination
of
powers
of
a
primitive
nth
root
of
unity:

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<msub>
<mi>X</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>j</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<msub>
<mi>X</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msub>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>j</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>+</mo>
<mo>.3</mo>
<mo>+</mo>
<msub>
<mi>X</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>j</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
x_{j}=\sum
_{k}X_{k}\cdot
z^{k\cdot
j}=X_{1}z^{1\cdot
j}+\cdots
+X_{n}\cdot
z^{n\cdot
j}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
x_{j}=\sum
_{k}X_{k}\cdot
z^{k\cdot
j}=X_{1}z^{1\cdot
j}+\cdots
+X_{n}\cdot
z^{n\cdot
j}}

for
some
complex
numbers
X[1],
...
,
X[n]
and
every
integer
j.

This
is
a
form
of
[243]Fourier
analysis.
If
j
is
a
(discrete)
time
variable,
then
k
is
a
[244]frequency
and
X[k]
is
a
complex
[245]amplitude.

Choosing
for
the
primitive
nth
root
of
unity

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>i</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z=e^{\frac
{2\pi
i}{n}}=\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z=e^{\frac
{2\pi
i}{n}}=\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}+i\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
}{n}}}

allows
x[j]
to
be
expressed
as
a
linear
combination
of
cos
and
sin:

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<msub>
<mi>A</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mi>cos</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>j</mi>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<msub>
<mi>B</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mi>sin</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>j</mi>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
x_{j}=\sum
_{k}A_{k}\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
jk}{n}}+\sum
_{k}B_{k}\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
jk}{n}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
x_{j}=\sum
_{k}A_{k}\cos
{\frac
{2\pi
jk}{n}}+\sum
_{k}B_{k}\sin
{\frac
{2\pi
jk}{n}}.}

This
is
a
[246]discrete
Fourier
transform.

Summation

[[247]edit]

Let
SR(n)
be
the
sum
of
all
the
nth
roots
of
unity,
primitive
or
not.
Then

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>SR</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow>
<mo>{</mo>
<mtable
columnalign="left
left"
rowspacing=".2em"
columnspacing="1em"
displaystyle="false">
<mtr>
<mtd>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
</mtd>
<mtd>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mtd>
</mtr>
<mtr>
<mtd>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
</mtd>
<mtd>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>></mo>
<mn>1.</mn>
</mtd>
</mtr>
</mtable>
<mo
fence="true"
stretchy="true"
symmetric="true"></mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SR}
(n)={\begin{cases}1,&n=1\\0,&n>1.\end{cases}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SR}
(n)={\begin{cases}1,&n=1\\0,&n>1.\end{cases}}}

This
is
an
immediate
consequence
of
[248]Vieta's
formulas.
In
fact,
the
nth
roots
of
unity
being
the
roots
of
the
polynomial
X^
n
-
1,
their
sum
is
the
[249]coefficient
of
degree
n
-
1,
which
is
either
1
or
0
according
whether
n
=
1
or
n
>
1.

Alternatively,
for
n
=
1
there
is
nothing
to
prove,
and
for
n
>
1
there
exists
a
root
z
!=
1
-
since
the
set
S
of
all
the
nth
roots
of
unity
is
a
[250]group,
z
S
=
S,
so
the
sum
satisfies
z
SR(n)
=
SR(n),
whence
SR(n)
=
0.

Let
SP(n)
be
the
sum
of
all
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity.
Then

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>SP</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>µ</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SP}
(n)=\mu
(n),}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SP}
(n)=\mu
(n),}

where
µ(n)
is
the
[251]Möbius
function.

In
the
section
[252]Elementary
properties,
it
was
shown
that
if
R(n)
is
the
set
of
all
nth
roots
of
unity
and
P(n)
is
the
set
of
primitive
ones,
R(n)
is
a
disjoint
union
of
the
P(n):

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi
mathvariant="normal">R</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>&#x22C3;</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mi
mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>d</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{R}
(n)=\bigcup
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{P}
(d),}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{R}
(n)=\bigcup
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{P}
(d),}

This
implies

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>SR</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mi>SP</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>d</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SR}
(n)=\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{SP}
(d).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SR}
(n)=\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\operatorname
{SP}
(d).}

Applying
the
[253]Möbius
inversion
formula
gives

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>SP</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mi>µ</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>d</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mi>SR</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>n</mi>
<mi>d</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SP}
(n)=\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\mu
(d)\operatorname
{SR}
\left({\frac
{n}{d}}\right).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\operatorname
{SP}
(n)=\sum
_{d\,|\,n}\mu
(d)\operatorname
{SR}
\left({\frac
{n}{d}}\right).}

In
this
formula,
if
d
<
n,
then
SR(&#8288;n/d&#8288;)
=
0
,
and
for
d
=
n:
SR(&#8288;n/d&#8288;)
=
1.
Therefore,
SP(n)
=
µ(n).

This
is
the
special
case
c[n](1)
of
[254]Ramanujan's
sum
c[n](s),^[255][10]
defined
as
the
sum
of
the
sth
powers
of
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity:

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>c</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>s</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munderover>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac
linethickness="0">
<mrow>
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mo
movablelimits="true"
form="prefix">gcd</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>a</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munderover>
<msup>
<mi>e</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>p</mi>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mi>a</mi>
<mi>n</mi>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mi>s</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
c_{n}(s)=\sum
_{a=1
\atop
\gcd(a,n)=1}^{n}e^{2\pi
i{\frac
{a}{n}}s}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
c_{n}(s)=\sum
_{a=1
\atop
\gcd(a,n)=1}^{n}e^{2\pi
i{\frac
{a}{n}}s}.}

Orthogonality

[[256]edit]

From
the
summation
formula
follows
an
[257]orthogonality
relationship:
for
j
=
1,
...
,
n
and
j'
=
1,
...
,
n

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<munderover>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munderover>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mover>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
accent="false">¯</mo>
</mover>
</mrow>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msup>
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>'</mo>
</msup>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msub>
<mi>d</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<msup>
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>'</mo>
</msup>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\sum
_{k=1}^{n}{\overline
{z^{j\cdot
k}}}\cdot
z^{j'\cdot
k}=n\cdot
\delta
_{j,j'}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\sum
_{k=1}^{n}{\overline
{z^{j\cdot
k}}}\cdot
z^{j'\cdot
k}=n\cdot
\delta
_{j,j'}}

where
d
is
the
[258]Kronecker
delta
and
z
is
any
primitive
nth
root
of
unity.

The
n
×
n
[259]matrix
U
whose
(j,
k)th
entry
is

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi>U</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>n</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mn>1</mn>
<mn>2</mn>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
U_{j,k}=n^{-{\frac
{1}{2}}}\cdot
z^{j\cdot
k}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
U_{j,k}=n^{-{\frac
{1}{2}}}\cdot
z^{j\cdot
k}}

defines
a
[260]discrete
Fourier
transform.
Computing
the
inverse
transformation
using
[261]Gaussian
elimination
requires
[262]O(n^3)
operations.
However,
it
follows
from
the
orthogonality
that
U
is
[263]unitary.
That
is,

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<munderover>
<mo>\sum</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munderover>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mover>
<msub>
<mi>U</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
accent="false">¯</mo>
</mover>
</mrow>
<mo>
·
</mo>
<msub>
<mi>U</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<msup>
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>'</mo>
</msup>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>=</mo>
<msub>
<mi>d</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<msup>
<mi>j</mi>
<mo>'</mo>
</msup>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\sum
_{k=1}^{n}{\overline
{U_{j,k}}}\cdot
U_{k,j'}=\delta
_{j,j'},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\sum
_{k=1}^{n}{\overline
{U_{j,k}}}\cdot
U_{k,j'}=\delta
_{j,j'},}

and
thus
the
inverse
of
U
is
simply
the
complex
conjugate.
(This
fact
was
first
noted
by
[264]Gauss
when
solving
the
problem
of
[265]trigonometric
interpolation.)
The
straightforward
application
of
U
or
its
inverse
to
a
given
vector
requires
O(n^2)
operations.
The
[266]fast
Fourier
transform
algorithms
reduces
the
number
of
operations
further
to
O(n
log
n).

Cyclotomic
polynomials

[[267]edit]
Main
article:
[268]Cyclotomic
polynomial

The
[269]zeros
of
the
polynomial

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>p</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
p(z)=z^{n}-1}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
p(z)=z^{n}-1}

are
precisely
the
nth
roots
of
unity,
each
with
[270]multiplicity
1.
The
nth
[271]cyclotomic
polynomial
is
defined
by
the
fact
that
its
zeros
are
precisely
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity,
each
with
multiplicity
1.

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi
mathvariant="normal">F</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<munderover>
<mo>\prod</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>f</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>n</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
</munderover>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<msub>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>k</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\Phi
_{n}(z)=\prod
_{k=1}^{\varphi
(n)}(z-z_{k})}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\Phi
_{n}(z)=\prod
_{k=1}^{\varphi
(n)}(z-z_{k})}

where
z[1],
z[2],
z[3],
...,
z[f(n)]
are
the
primitive
nth
roots
of
unity,
and
f(n)
is
[272]Euler's
totient
function.
The
polynomial
F[n](z)
has
integer
coefficients
and
is
an
[273]irreducible
polynomial
over
the
rational
numbers
(that
is,
it
cannot
be
written
as
the
product
of
two
positive-degree
polynomials
with
rational
coefficients).^[274][9]
The
case
of
prime
n,
which
is
easier
than
the
general
assertion,
follows
by
applying
[275]Eisenstein's
criterion
to
the
polynomial

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{(z+1)^{n}-1}{(z+1)-1}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{(z+1)^{n}-1}{(z+1)-1}},}

and
expanding
via
the
[276]binomial
theorem.

Every
nth
root
of
unity
is
a
primitive
dth
root
of
unity
for
exactly
one
positive
[277]divisor
d
of
n.
This
implies
that^[278][9]

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>z</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mo>\prod</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo
stretchy="false">|</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</munder>
<msub>
<mi
mathvariant="normal">F</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>d</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
z^{n}-1=\prod
_{d\,|\,n}\Phi
_{d}(z).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
z^{n}-1=\prod
_{d\,|\,n}\Phi
_{d}(z).}

This
formula
represents
the
[279]factorization
of
the
polynomial
z^n
-
1
into
irreducible
factors:

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle

<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

<mtr>
<mtd>
<msup>

</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\begin{aligned}z^{1}-1&=z-1\\z^{2}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)\\z^{3}-1&=(z-1
)(z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{4}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)(z^{2}+1)\\z^{5}-1&=(z-1)(z^{4}
+z^{3}+z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{6}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)(z^{2}+z+1)(z^{2}-z+1)\\z^
{7}-1&=(z-1)(z^{6}+z^{5}+z^{4}+z^{3}+z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{8}-1&=(z-1)(
z+1)(z^{2}+1)(z^{4}+1)\\\end{aligned}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\begin{aligned}z^{1}-1&=z-1\\z^{2}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)\\z^{3}-1&=(z-1
)(z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{4}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)(z^{2}+1)\\z^{5}-1&=(z-1)(z^{4}
+z^{3}+z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{6}-1&=(z-1)(z+1)(z^{2}+z+1)(z^{2}-z+1)\\z^
{7}-1&=(z-1)(z^{6}+z^{5}+z^{4}+z^{3}+z^{2}+z+1)\\z^{8}-1&=(z-1)(
z+1)(z^{2}+1)(z^{4}+1)\\\end{aligned}}}

Applying
[280]Möbius
inversion
to
the
formula
gives

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle

scriptlevel="0">
<msub>
<mi
