Revenue
Increase
US$1
billion
(2022)^[107][4]
Owner

*
[108]GIC
Private
Limited
*
[109]The
Blackstone
Group^[110][5]

(2021-present)
Members
25
million

Number
of
employees

1,400^[111][6]
Website
[112]www.ancestry.com
[113]Edit
this
at
Wikidata

Ancestry.com
LLC
is
an
American
[114]genealogy
company
based
in
[115]Lehi,
Utah.
The
largest
[116]for-profit
genealogy
company
in
the
world,
it
operates
a
network
of
genealogical,
historical
records,
and
related
[117]genetic
genealogy
websites.
It
is
owned
by
[118]The
Blackstone
Group,
which
acquired
the
company
on
December
4,
2020,
in
a
deal
valued
at
$4.7
billion.^[119][7]^[120][8]^[121][9]

As
of
2022,
the
company
said
it
had
provided
access
to
30
billion
historical
records,
tripling
its
November
2018
figure
of
10
billion
records.^[122][10]^[123][11]
In
2018
it
also
reported
having
3
million
paying
subscribers,
and
to
have
sold
18
million
[124]DNA
kits
to
customers.^[125][11]
By
2023,
Ancestry
was
the
largest
provider
of
consumer
DNA
testing
in
the
world
with
a
network
of
over
25
million
users,^[126][12]
and
Ancestry
DNA
testing
is
now
available
in
128
countries.

As
well
as
its
main
website,
Ancestry
operates
country-specific
versions
for
Australia,
Canada,
France,
Germany,
Italy,
Mexico,
Sweden
and
the
United
Kingdom.^[127][13]

History

[[128]edit]

Ancestry

[[129]edit]

1983

[[130]edit]

Ancestry
Publishing
was
founded
in
1983,
producing
genealogical
data
in
print
form,
with
more
than
40
family
history
magazine
titles
and
genealogy
reference
books
published.^[131][14]^[132][15]

1990-1999

[[133]edit]

In
1990,
Paul
Brent
Allen
and
Dan
Taggart,
two
[134]Brigham
Young
University
graduates,
founded
Infobases
and
began
offering
[135]Latter-day
Saints
(LDS)
publications
on
[136]floppy
disks.
In
1988,
Allen
had
worked
at
[137]Folio
Corporation,
founded
by
his
brother
Curt
and
his
brother-in-law
[138]Brad
Pelo.
The
service
was
initially
to
help
members
of
the
church
to
research
their
ancestors.

Infobases'
first
products
were
[139]floppy
disks
and
[140]compact
disks
sold
from
the
back
seat
of
the
founders'
car.
In
1994,
Infobases
was
named
among
[141]Inc.
magazine's
500
fastest-growing
companies.^[142][16]
Their
first
offering
on
[143]CD
was
the
LDS
Collectors
Edition,
released
in
April
1995,
selling
for
$299.95,^[144][17]
which
was
offered
in
an
online
version
in
August
1995.^[145][18]
Ancestry
officially
went
online
with
the
launch
of
Ancestry.com
in
1996.^[146][15]

On
January
1,
1997,
Infobases'
parent
company,
Western
Standard
Publishing,
purchased
Ancestry,
Inc.,^[147][19]
publisher
of
[148]Ancestry
magazine
and
genealogy
books.
Western
Standard
Publishing's
CEO
was
[149]Joseph
A.
Cannon,
one
of
the
principal
owners
of
[150]Geneva
Steel.^[151][20]

In
July
1997,
Allen
and
Taggart
purchased
Western
Standard's
interest
in
Ancestry,
Inc.
At
the
time,
[152]Brad
Pelo
was
[153]president
and
CEO
of
Infobases,
and
president
of
Western
Standard.
Less
than
six
months
earlier,
he
had
been
president
of
Folio
Corporation,
whose
digital
technology
Infobases
was
using.
In
March
1997,
Folio
was
sold
to
[154]Open
Market
for
$45
million.^[155][21]
The
first
public
evidence
of
the
change
in
ownership
of
Ancestry
magazine
came
with
the
July/August
1997
issue,
which
showed
a
newly
reorganized
Ancestry,
Inc.,
as
its
publisher.
That
issue's
masthead
also
included
the
first
use
of
the
Ancestry.com
web
address.

More
growth
for
Infobases
occurred
in
July
1997,
when
Ancestry,
Inc.
purchased
[156]Bookcraft,
Inc.,
a
publisher
of
books
written
by
leaders
and
officers
of
the
LDS
Church.^[157][22]^[158][23]
Infobases
had
published
many
of
Bookcraft's
books
as
part
of
its
LDS
Collector's
Library.
Pelo
also
announced
that
Ancestry's
product
line
would
be
greatly
expanded
in
both
CDs
and
online.
[159]Alan
Ashton,
a
longtime
investor
in
Infobases
and
founder
of
[160]WordPerfect,
was
its
chairman
of
the
board.

Allen
and
Taggart
began
running
Ancestry,
Inc.
independently
from
Infobases
in
July
1997,
and
began
creating
one
of
the
largest
online
subscription-based
genealogy
database
services.^[161][24]

In
April
1999,
to
better
focus
on
its
Ancestry.com
and
MyFamily.com
Internet
businesses,
Infobases
sold
the
Bookcraft
brand
name
and
its
catalog
of
print
books
to
its
major
competitor
in
the
LDS
book
market,
[162]Deseret
Book.
Included
in
the
sale
were
the
rights
to
Infobases'
LDS
Collectors
Library
on
CD.
A
year
earlier,
Deseret
Book
had
released
a
competing
product
called
GospeLink,
and
the
two
products
were
combined
as
a
single
product
by
Deseret
Book.^[163][25]^[164][26]

The
MyFamily.com
website
launched
in
December
1998,
with
additional
free
sites
beginning
in
March
1999.^[165][27]
The
site
generated
one-million
registered
users
within
its
first
140
days.^[166][24]
The
company
raised
more
than
US$90
million
in
venture
capital
from
investors^[167][24]
and
changed
its
name
on
November
17,
1999,
from
Ancestry.com,
Inc.
to
MyFamily.com,
Inc.
Its
three
Internet
genealogy
sites
were
then
called
Ancestry.com,
FamilyHistory.com,
and
MyFamily.com.^[168][28]
Sales
were
about
US$62
million
for
2002
and
US$99
million
for
2003.^[169][29]
[170][220px-Ancestry_dot_com_headquarters.jpg]
Former
Ancestry.com
headquarters
in
[171]Provo,
Utah

2000-2009

[[172]edit]

In
March
2004,
the
company,
which
had
outgrown
its
call
center
in
[173]Orem,
Utah,
opened
a
new
[174]call
center,
which
accommodated
about
700
agents
at
a
time,
in
[175]Provo.^[176][30]
[177]Heritage
Makers
was
acquired
by
MyFamily.com
in
September
2005.^[178][31]

On
November
5,
2009,
Ancestry.com
became
a
publicly
traded
company
on
[179]NASDAQ
(symbol:
ACOM),
with
an
initial
public
offering
of
7.4
million
shares
priced
at
$13.50
per
share,
underwritten
by
[180]Morgan
Stanley,
[181]Bank
of
America,
[182]Merrill
Lynch,
[183]Jefferies
&
Company,
[184]Piper
Jaffray,
and
[185]BMO
Capital
Markets.^[186][32]

2010-2019

[[187]edit]

In
2010,
Ancestry
sold
its
book
publishing
assets
to
[188]Turner
Publishing
Company.^[189][33]

In
2010,
Ancestry.com
expanded
its
domestic
operations
with
the
opening
of
an
office
in
[190]San
Francisco,
California,
staffed
with
brand
new
engineering,
product,
and
marketing
teams
geared
toward
developing
some
of
Ancestry's
cutting-edge
technology
and
services.
In
2011,
Ancestry
launched
an
[191]Android
and
[192]iOS
app.^[193][34]^[194][35]

In
December
2011,
Ancestry.com
moved
the
[195]Social
Security
Death
Index
search
behind
a
[196]paywall
and
stopped
displaying
the
Social
Security
information
of
people
who
had
died
within
the
past
10
years,
because
of
[197]identity
theft
concerns.^[198][36]

In
March
2012,
Ancestry.com
acquired
the
collection
of
DNA
assets
from
[199]GeneTree.^[200][37]

In
September
2012,
Ancestry.com
expanded
its
international
operations
with
the
opening
of
its
European
headquarters
in
[201]Dublin,
Ireland.
The
Dublin
office
includes
a
new
call
center
for
international
customers,
as
well
as
product,
marketing,
and
engineering
teams.^[202][38]^[203][39]

In
October
2012,
Ancestry.com
agreed
to
be
acquired
by
a
private
equity
group
consisting
of
[204]Permira
Advisers
LLP,
members
of
Ancestry.com's
management
team,
including
CEO
Tim
Sullivan
and
CFO
Howard
Hochhauser,
and
Spectrum
Equity,
for
$32
per
share
or
around
$1.6
billion.^[205][40]
At
the
same
time,
Ancestry.com
purchased
a
photo
digitization
and
sharing
service
called
[206]1000Memories.^[207][41]

In
2013,
Ancestry
acquired
[208]Find
a
Grave
from
Jim
Tipton,
who
had
created
the
original
site
in
1995.
Ancestry
subsequently
launched
a
redesigned
version
of
Find
a
Grave
in
2017.

On
July
16,
2015,
Ancestry
launched
AncestryHealth,
and
announced
the
appointment
of
Cathy
A.
Petti
as
its
Chief
Health
Officer.^[209][42]
That
year,
Ancestry
partnered
with
the
[210]Google
subsidiary,
[211]Calico,
to
focus
on
longevity
research
and
therapeutics,
in
an
effort
to
investigate
human
heredity
of
lifespan.^[212][43]^[213][44]

In
April
2016,
[214]GIC
Private
Limited
(a
sovereign
wealth
fund
owned
by
the
Government
of
Singapore)
and
[215]Silver
Lake
(a
private
equity
fund
manager)
bought
equity
stakes
in
Ancestry.com.^[216][45]
The
estimated
market
value
of
Ancestry.com
in
2017
was
more
than
$3
billion.^[217][46]

In
June
2017,
Ancestry.com
stated
that
it
was
migrating
all
of
its
applications
and
data
to
[218]Amazon
Web
Services
(AWS).^[219][47]^[220][48]

Through
vintage
photographs,
a
woman
was
able
to
document
eight
generations
of
her
family,
dating
back
to
1805,
including
an
interracial
couple.^[221][49]
A
controversial
Ancestry.com
advertisement
had
run
on
television
stations
in
[222]Utah,
showing
a
slavery-era
interracial
couple.
The
advertisement
was
criticized
by
a
news
correspondent
for
Boston
radio
station
[223]WBUR-FM
and
[224]MSNBC,
and
law
professor
[225]Melissa
Murray,
on
the
grounds
that
it
romanticized
slavery
in
the
[226]antebellum
South.
In
April
2019,
Ancestry
withdrew
the
advertisement
with
an
apology.^[227][50]

In
November
2018,
Ancestry
claimed
to
have
over
10
billion
digitized
records
and
over
three-million
paying
customers.^[228][51]

In
December
2018,
after
authorities
arrested
the
[229]Golden
State
Killer
and
used
[230]GEDmatch
to
solve
the
case,
Ancestry.com
and
[231]23andMe
announced
a
data
policy
that
they
would
not
allow
their
DNA
profiles
to
be
used
for
crime
solving
without
a
valid
legal
process
such
as
a
[232]search
warrant,
as
they
believe
it
violates
users'
privacy.^[233][52]^[234][53]
In
the
2021
case
of
the
[235]murder
of
George
Seitz,
Ancestry.com
was
used
to
help
identify
the
remains
of
a
crime
victim.^[236][54]

2020-present

[[237]edit]

In
August
2020,
[238]The
Blackstone
Group
announced
plans
to
acquire
Ancestry
for
$4.7
billion,^[239][7]
and
in
December
2020
the
acquisition
occurred.

In
February
2021,
Ancestry
announced
[240]Deb
Liu,
a
former
Facebook
executive,
as
their
CEO
effective
March
1.^[241][1]

In
November
2021,
Ancestry
announced
the
acquisition
of
French
Genealogy
Company
[242]Geneanet.^[243][55]

In
March
2023,
Ancestry
announced
that
it
had
won
a
contract
to
digitize
over
3
million
British
Army
service
records,
which
it
would
release
from
2024
through
2029.
In
February
2021
the
Ministry
Of
Defence
commenced
transferring
9.7
million
military
records
for
individuals
with
a
discharge
date
before
31
December
1963
to
The
National
Archives
UK,
its
largest
record
transfer
in
the
history
of
the
organization.^[244][56]

AncestryDNA

[[245]edit]

AncestryDNA
is
a
subsidiary
of
Ancestry
LLC.
AncestryDNA
offers
a
direct-to-consumer
[246]genealogical
DNA
test.^[247][57]
Consumers
provide
a
sample
of
their
DNA
to
the
company
for
analysis.
AncestryDNA
then
uses
DNA
sequences
to
infer
family
relationships
with
other
Ancestry
DNA
users,
and
to
infer
"ancestral
regions"^[248][58]
(previously
"[249]ethnicity
estimates").^[250][59]
Previously,
Ancestry.com
also
offered
paternal
[251]Y-chromosome
DNA
and
maternal
[252]mitochondrial
DNA
tests,
but
those
were
discontinued
in
June
2014.^[253][60]
The
company
describes
the
technical
process
of
testing
in
a
series
of
scientific
[254]white
papers.^[255][61]
In
July
2020,
the
company
claimed
that
their
database
contained
18
million
completed
DNA
kits
bought
by
customers.^[256][62]^[257][51]^[258][63]

Ancestry
DNA
is
commonly
used
for
[259]donor
conceived
persons
to
find
their
biological
siblings
and
in
some
cases
their
[260]sperm
or
[261]egg
donor.^[262][64]

The
testing
itself
is
performed
by
[263]Quest
Diagnostics.^[264][65]

AncestryDNA
offers
the
option
to
participate
in
their
Human
Diversity
Project,
a
"scientific
research
project
aimed
at
helping
scientists
better
understand
population
history,
population
movements,
and
human
health".^[265][66]^[266][67]

Members
can
also
pay
an
additional
fee
to
access
DNA
traits,
which
range
from
predicted
physical
traits
to
limited
health
data.

Know
Your
Pet
DNA

[[267]edit]

Since
2023,
Ancestry
has
also
offered
genetic
testing
for
pets,
which
at
the
moment
is
limited
to
dogs.^[268][3]
The
test
compares
the
DNA
to
over
400
breeds.

Find
a
Grave

[[269]edit]

Main
article:
[270]Find
a
Grave

On
September
30,
2013,
Ancestry.com
announced
its
acquisition
of
[271]Find
a
Grave.
Site
editor
Jim
Tipton
said
of
the
purchase
that
Ancestry.com
had
"been
linking
and
driving
traffic
to
the
site
for
several
years.
Burial
information
is
a
wonderful
source
for
people
researching
their
family
history".
Ancestry.com
launched
a
mobile
app
in
March
2014.^[272][68]

Fold3

[[273]edit]

Fold3
is
a
premium
portal
that
specializes
in
military
genealogy.
Subscribers
access
an
online
database
with
military
records,
including
stories,
photos,
and
personal
documents.
It
was
rebranded
as
Forces
War
Records
in
the
[274]British
&
Commonwealth
nations
in
April
2023.^[275][69]

The
website
also
features
the
[276]Guion
Miller
Roll,
an
[277]Eastern
Cherokee
tribal
roll.^[278][70]

Footnote

[[279]edit]

Ancestry.com
acquired
[280]iArchives,
Inc.,
and
its
service
footnote.com,
in
2010.
The
purchase
brought
in
assets
including
processes
for
digitizing
[281]microfilm.^[282][71]^[283][72]
Footnote
was
rebranded
Fold3
in
2011.^[284][73]

Geneanet

[[285]edit]

Main
article:
[286]Geneanet

On
August
31,
2021,
Ancestry.com
announced
its
acquisition
of
[287]Geneanet.
Geneanet
explains
that
the
acquisition
by
Ancestry
is
the
consequence
of
the
failure
of
the
Filae
negotiations
with
the
birth
of
a
formidable
competitor.
The
Geneanet.org
site,
which
must
remain
autonomous,
indicates
that
it
will
give
access
to
many
databases
indexed
by
Ancestry
within
the
framework
of
Premium
subscriptions.^[288][74]

Archives.com

[[289]edit]

Archives.com
was
bought
by
Ancestry
for
$100
million
in
2012.^[290][75]
Archives.com
is
a
genealogy
website
specializing
in
census
and
vital
records.
As
of
November
29,
2023,
Archives.com
claimed
11.8
billion
photos,
newspapers,
census,
and
vital
records
in
its
collections.^[291][76]

Newspapers.com

[[292]edit]

In
2012,
Ancestry
spun
off
its
digitized
online
newspaper
components
into
a
standalone
service,
Newspapers.com.^[293][77]
By
2024,
the
site
had
over
25,000
newspapers
able
to
be
searched,
including
some
from
ten
different
countries.

The
Web
site's
principal
competitor
is
[294]NewspaperArchive,
which
claims
it
has
online
newspapers
dating
from
1607
worldwide,
and
its
index
in
March
2024
included
over
16,000
newspapers.^[295][78]
Both
websites
have
similar
models
for
increasing
their
databases:
striking
deals
with
libraries,
publishers
and
historical
organizations
to
scan
the
publications
for
free
to
include
in
their
database.
Some
participants
see
the
process
of
free
scanning
as
an
easier,
cheaper
and
quicker
way
to
get
their
publications
online
than
working
through
the
U.S.
government-operated
[296]National
Digital
Newspaper
Program.^[297][79]^[298][80]

RootsWeb

[[299]edit]

RootsWeb,
acquired
by
Ancestry
in
June
2000,
is
a
free
genealogy
community
that
uses
online
forums,
mailing
lists,
and
other
resources
to
help
people
research
their
family
history.
Users
can
upload
[300]GEDCOM
files
of
their
information
for
others
to
search
at
the
WorldConnect
portion
of
the
site.
Trees
uploaded
to
WorldConnect
are
searchable
at
both
the
RootsWeb
and
Ancestry
Web
sites.

On
December
20,
2017,
a
file
containing
300,000
RootsWeb
user
names,
passwords,
and
email
addresses
was
exposed
to
the
Internet.
The
300,000
records
were
from
RootsWeb
surname
list
service;
55,000
of
those
records
were
also
Ancestry.com
login
credentials.^[301][81]
By
2024,
the
hosted
Web
sites
were
all
read-only,
disabling
all
user
logins.

We
Remember

[[302]edit]

We
Remember
is
a
free
online
memorial
platform,^[303][82]
which
was
launched
by
Ancestry
in
November
2017.^[304][83]^[305][84]
It
allows
users
to
create
a
space
to
preserve
and
share
photos
and
videos
about
the
deceased.^[306][85]

Forces
War
Records

[[307]edit]

Forces
War
Records
was
a
low
cost
provider
of
transcribed
genealogical
data
from
British
sources.
The
irony
was
that
much
of
the
content
behind
their
paywall
had
simply
been
taken
from
public
domain
sources.
As
a
consequence,
there
was
a
lack
of
transparency
as
to
where
they
sourced
their
content
from.^[308][86]^[309][87]
(See
[310]Wikipedia:Reliable
sources/Noticeboard/Archive
315#RfC:
forces-war-records.co.uk)
They
came
under
criticism
for
difficulties
in
canceling
subscriptions,
with
a
complaint
about
their
misleading
marketing
being
upheld
by
the
Advertising
Standards
Authority.^[311][88]

Acquired
by
Ancestry
on
May
24,
2021,
the
press
release
announced
that
'Forces
War
Records
is
a
British
military
genealogy-specialist
website
with
a
unique
product
that
helps
people
both
discover
and
contextualize
their
family's
military
history.'^[312][89]
Given
that
Fold3
had
a
negative
perception
as
"US-centric",^[313][90]
the
same
dataset
offerings
and
web
architecture
were
used
in
the
UK,
albeit
branded
as
Forces
War
Records,
from
April
2023
onwards.^[314][69]
The
provision
of
service
records
for
the
first
time
ever,
via
this
brand,
as
a
consequence
of
the
linkage
with
fold3,
has
reinvigorated
the
brand.
Not
only
transcriptions,
but
also
images
of
source
documents
are
now
available
to
the
subscriber.^[315][91]
In
support
of
the
brand
being
relaunched
as
a
premium
portal
that
specializes
in
military
genealogy,
half
a
million
records
were
added
to
the
(FWR/Fold3)
portal
in
July
2023.^[316][92]

Past
products

[[317]edit]

*
Family
Origins^[318][93]^[319][94]^[320][95]
*
[321]Family
Tree
Maker
was
purchased
by
Software
MacKiev
in
2016.^[322][96]^[323][97]
*
Genealogy.com,
which
maintains
a
genealogy
research
website,
was
acquired
by
MyFamily.com
in
2003.^[324][98]
*
Generations
Family
Tree
(originally
called
"[325]Reunion
for
Windows")^[326][99]
*
MyFamily.com
allowed
members
to
create
private
family,
or
group,
websites.
In
May
2010,
MyFamily
closed
its
[327]Bellevue,
Washington,
development
office,
effectively
letting
its
entire
staff
go
since
none
of
the
staff
accepted
an
offer
to
move
to
Provo.
Ancestry
shut
down
MyFamily.com
on
September
5,
2014.^[328][100]
At
the
time
of
the
shutdown,
MyFamily
had
not
resolved
discontent
with
the
downloading
process,
which
consisted
of
capturing
miscellaneous
uncatalogued
photos,
with
alphanumeric
names
and
no
data
attached,
and
various
calendar
documents,
thus
leaving
behind
the
associated
data,
File
Cabinet
documents,
family
recipes,
and
all
other
information.^[329][100]
*
ROOTS
software
series
by
CommSoft^[330][101]^[331][102]
was
one
of
the
first
publishers
of
series
of
[332]genealogy
software
programs,
created
in
the
1980s,
and
available
until
1997.
Commsoft
released
the
following:
ROOTS89
for
the
[333]Heath
H-8
series
of
personal
computers;
ROOTS/M
for
the
[334]CP/M
operating
system;
and
ROOTS
II
for
[335]MS-DOS,
followed
by
ROOTS
III
and
ROOTS
IV;
and
ROOTS
V
for
Windows
along
with
Visual
ROOTS
for
[336]Microsoft
Windows.
*
Ultimate
Family
Tree
(UFT)^[337][101]^[338][103]

See
also

Project

Inc.

[542]^
[543]"Personnel
searching
[via]
Forces
War
Records".
[Researching]
Soldiers
and
their
units.
Great
War
Forum.
July
9,
2015.
Retrieved
October
22,
2024.
"Just
my
opinion
you
understand,
but
[in
2015]
I
have
found
Forces
War
Records
to
be
virtually
useless:
in
particular,
I
have
been
charged
money
for
information
that
is
available
for
free
elsewhere.
In
some
cases
the
information
they
offer
is
inaccurate
and
downright
misleading
(e.g.
the
guesswork
as
to
which
medals
a
soldier
should
have
earned).
With
the
exception
of
a
small
number
of
WW2
Home
Guard
transcribed
items
(not
the
original
documents),
I
did
not
come
across
anything
that
was
not
available
better,
and
cheaper/free,
elsewhere.
Many
of
the
documents
I
looked
for,
which
they
claim
to
have,
(e.g.
WW1
medal
records),
turned
out
to
be
transcriptions,
not
the
original
documents
themselves
(which
Ancestry
have).
When
I
cancelled
my
subscription
they
continued
to
charge
me
and
I
ended
up
paying
for
an
extra
month.
Again,
I
stress
that
this
is
just
my
own
experience,
and
my
personal
point
of
view
of
this
worthless
company,
which
I
would
strongly
advise
everyone
to
give
a
miss
to,
and
which
the
internet
would
be
better
off
without.
All
in
my
own
opinion
of
course......"
87.
[544]^
[545]""Forces
War
Records"
website
-
user
review
sought".
Using
the
technology.
Great
War
Forum.
September
20,
2019.
Retrieved
October
22,
2024.
"In
short,
I
wouldn't
bother.
They
sort
of
imply
that
you
are
going
to
get
access
to
someone's
complete
service
record
if
you
pay.
So,
you
pay.
And
you
don't
get
those
papers
at
all.
What
you
get
is
a
sort
of
summary
sheet
and
links
to
other
sites
(that
also
want
you
to
pay
in
most
cases)
and
general
links
about
the
unit
your
soldier/sailor/airman
served
in
and
general
medal
info.
Frankly,
it
is
something
of
a
let
down!"
88.

been

new

Origins

Technology
over

have

[95]Wikidata

Appearance
(BUTTON)

to

hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Finding
values
for
variables
that
make
an
equation
true
[96][50px-Question_book-new.svg.png]
This
article
relies
largely
or
entirely
on
a
[97]single
source.
Relevant
discussion
may
be
found
on
the
[98]talk
page.
Please
help
[99]improve
this
article
by
[100]introducing
citations
to
additional
sources.
Find
sources:
[101]"Equation
solving"
-
[102]news
·
[103]newspapers
·
[104]books
·
[105]scholar
·
[106]JSTOR
(December
2009)
"Solution
(mathematics)"
redirects
here.
For
solutions
of
constraint
satisfaction
problems,
see
[107]Constraint
satisfaction
problem
§
Resolution.
For
solutions
of
mathematical
optimization
problems,
see
[108]Feasible
solution.
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mover>
<munder>
<mrow>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mo>-</mo>
<mi>b</mi>
<mo>±</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<msup>
<mi>b</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>4</mn>
<mi>a</mi>
<mi>c</mi>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>a</mi>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mrow
/>
</munder>
<mrow
/>
</mover>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\overset
{}{\underset
{}{x={\frac
{-b\pm
{\sqrt
{b^{2}-4ac}}}{2a}}}}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\overset
{}{\underset
{}{x={\frac
{-b\pm
{\sqrt
{b^{2}-4ac}}}{2a}}}}}}
The
[109]quadratic
formula,
the
symbolic
solution
of
the
[110]quadratic
equation
ax^2
+
bx
+
c
=
0
[111]Illustration
of
Newton's
method
An
example
of
using
[112]Newton-Raphson
method
to
solve
numerically
the
equation
f(x)
=
0

In
[113]mathematics,
to
solve
an
equation
is
to
find
its
solutions,
which
are
the
values
([114]numbers,
[115]functions,
[116]sets,
etc.)
that
fulfill
the
condition
stated
by
the
[117]equation,
consisting
generally
of
two
[118]expressions
related
by
an
[119]equals
sign.
When
seeking
a
solution,
one
or
more
[120]variables
are
designated
as
[121]unknowns.
A
solution
is
an
assignment
of
values
to
the
unknown
variables
that
makes
the
equality
in
the
equation
true.
In
other
words,
a
solution
is
a
value
or
a
collection
of
values
(one
for
each
unknown)
such
that,
when
[122]substituted
for
the
unknowns,
the
equation
becomes
an
[123]equality.
A
solution
of
an
equation
is
often
called
a
root
of
the
equation,
particularly
but
not
only
for
[124]polynomial
equations.
The
set
of
all
solutions
of
an
equation
is
its
[125]solution
set.

An
equation
may
be
solved
either
[126]numerically
or
symbolically.
Solving
an
equation
numerically
means
that
only
numbers
are
admitted
as
solutions.
Solving
an
equation
symbolically
means
that
expressions
can
be
used
for
representing
the
solutions.

For
example,
the
equation
x
+
y
=
2x
-
1
is
solved
for
the
unknown
x
by
the
expression
x
=
y
+
1,
because
substituting
y
+
1
for
x
in
the
equation
results
in
(y
+
1)
+
y
=
2(y
+
1)
-
1,
a
true
statement.
It
is
also
possible
to
take
the
variable
y
to
be
the
unknown,
and
then
the
equation
is
solved
by
y
=
x
-
1.
Or
x
and
y
can
both
be
treated
as
unknowns,
and
then
there
are
many
solutions
to
the
equation;
a
symbolic
solution
is
(x,
y)
=
(a
+
1,
a),
where
the
variable
a
may
take
any
value.
Instantiating
a
symbolic
solution
with
specific
numbers
gives
a
numerical
solution;
for
example,
a
=
0
gives
(x,
y)
=
(1,
0)
(that
is,
x
=
1,
y
=
0),
and
a
=
1
gives
(x,
y)
=
(2,
1).

The
distinction
between
known
variables
and
unknown
variables
is
generally
made
in
the
statement
of
the
problem,
by
phrases
such
as
"an
equation
in
x
and
y",
or
"solve
for
x
and
y",
which
indicate
the
unknowns,
here
x
and
y.
However,
it
is
common
to
reserve
x,
y,
z,
...
to
denote
the
unknowns,
and
to
use
a,
b,
c,
...
to
denote
the
known
variables,
which
are
often
called
[127]parameters.
This
is
typically
the
case
when
considering
[128]polynomial
equations,
such
as
[129]quadratic
equations.
However,
for
some
problems,
all
variables
may
assume
either
role.

Depending
on
the
context,
solving
an
equation
may
consist
to
find
either
any
solution
(finding
a
single
solution
is
enough),
all
solutions,
or
a
solution
that
satisfies
further
properties,
such
as
belonging
to
a
given
[130]interval.
When
the
task
is
to
find
the
solution
that
is
the
best
under
some
criterion,
this
is
an
[131]optimization
problem.
Solving
an
optimization
problem
is
generally
not
referred
to
as
"equation
solving",
as,
generally,
solving
methods
start
from
a
particular
solution
for
finding
a
better
solution,
and
repeating
the
process
until
finding
eventually
the
best
solution.

Overview

[[132]edit]

One
general
form
of
an
equation
is

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>f</mi>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
<msub>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
f\left(x_{1},\dots
,x_{n}\right)=c,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
f\left(x_{1},\dots
,x_{n}\right)=c,}

where
f
is
a
[133]function,
x[1],
...,
x[n]
are
the
unknowns,
and
c
is
a
constant.
Its
solutions
are
the
elements
of
the
[134]inverse
image
([135]fiber)

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>f</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OPEN">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">{</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<msub>
<mi>a</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
<msub>
<mi>a</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>(-</mo>
<mi>D</mi>
<mo>&#x2223;</mo>
<mi>f</mi>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<msub>
<mi>a</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msub>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>,</mo>
<msub>
<mi>a</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msub>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-CLOSE">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">}</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
f^{-1}(c)={\bigl
\{}(a_{1},\dots
,a_{n})\in
D\mid
f\left(a_{1},\dots
,a_{n}\right)=c{\bigr
\}},}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
f^{-1}(c)={\bigl
\{}(a_{1},\dots
,a_{n})\in
D\mid
f\left(a_{1},\dots
,a_{n}\right)=c{\bigr
\}},}

where
D
is
the
[136]domain
of
the
function
f.
The
set
of
solutions
can
be
the
[137]empty
set
(there
are
no
solutions),
a
[138]singleton
(there
is
exactly
one
solution),
finite,
or
infinite
(there
are
infinitely
many
solutions).

For
example,
an
equation
such
as

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>3</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>y</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>21</mn>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
3x+2y=21z,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
3x+2y=21z,}

with
unknowns
x,
y
and
z,
can
be
put
in
the
above
form
by
subtracting
21z
from
both
sides
of
the
equation,
to
obtain

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>3</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>y</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>21</mn>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
3x+2y-21z=0}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
3x+2y-21z=0}

In
this
particular
case
there
is
not
just
one
solution,
but
an
infinite
set
of
solutions,
which
can
be
written
using
[139]set
builder
notation
as

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OPEN">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">{</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>y</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>&#x2223;</mo>
<mn>3</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>y</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>21</mn>
<mi>z</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-CLOSE">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">}</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\bigl
\{}(x,y,z)\mid
3x+2y-21z=0{\bigr
\}}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\bigl
\{}(x,y,z)\mid
3x+2y-21z=0{\bigr
\}}.}

One
particular
solution
is
x
=
0,
y
=
0,
z
=
0.
Two
other
solutions
are
x
=
3,
y
=
6,
z
=
1,
and
x
=
8,
y
=
9,
z
=
2.
There
is
a
unique
[140]plane
in
[141]three-dimensional
space
which
passes
through
the
three
points
with
these
[142]coordinates,
and
this
plane
is
the
set
of
all
points
whose
coordinates
are
solutions
of
the
equation.

Solution
sets

[[143]edit]
[144][220px-Ellipse_in_coordinate_system_with_semi-axes_labelled.svg.pn
g]
The
solution
set
of
the
equation
&#8288;x^2/4&#8288;
+
y^2
=
1
forms
an
[145]ellipse
when
interpreted
as
a
set
of
[146]Cartesian
coordinate
pairs.
Main
article:
[147]Solution
set

The
[148]solution
set
of
a
given
set
of
equations
or
[149]inequalities
is
the
[150]set
of
all
its
solutions,
a
solution
being
a
[151]tuple
of
values,
one
for
each
[152]unknown,
that
satisfies
all
the
equations
or
inequalities.
If
the
[153]solution
set
is
empty,
then
there
are
no
values
of
the
unknowns
that
satisfy
simultaneously
all
equations
and
inequalities.

For
a
simple
example,
consider
the
equation

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>2.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
x^{2}=2.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
x^{2}=2.}

This
equation
can
be
viewed
as
a
[154]Diophantine
equation,
that
is,
an
equation
for
which
only
[155]integer
solutions
are
sought.
In
this
case,
the
solution
set
is
the
[156]empty
set,
since
2
is
not
the
[157]square
of
an
integer.
However,
if
one
searches
for
[158]real
solutions,
there
are
two
solutions,
SQRT
2
and
-
SQRT
2;
in
other
words,
the
solution
set
is
{
SQRT
2,
-
SQRT
2}.

When
an
equation
contains
several
unknowns,
and
when
one
has
several
equations
with
more
unknowns
than
equations,
the
solution
set
is
often
infinite.
In
this
case,
the
solutions
cannot
be
listed.
For
representing
them,
a
[159]parametrization
is
often
useful,
which
consists
of
expressing
the
solutions
in
terms
of
some
of
the
unknowns
or
auxiliary
variables.
This
is
always
possible
when
all
the
equations
are
[160]linear.

Such
infinite
solution
sets
can
naturally
be
interpreted
as
[161]geometric
shapes
such
as
[162]lines,
[163]curves
(see
picture),
[164]planes,
and
more
generally
[165]algebraic
varieties
or
[166]manifolds.
In
particular,
[167]algebraic
geometry
may
be
viewed
as
the
study
of
solution
sets
of
[168]algebraic
equations.

Methods
of
solution

[[169]edit]

The
methods
for
solving
equations
generally
depend
on
the
type
of
equation,
both
the
kind
of
expressions
in
the
equation
and
the
kind
of
values
that
may
be
assumed
by
the
unknowns.
The
variety
in
types
of
equations
is
large,
and
so
are
the
corresponding
methods.
Only
a
few
specific
types
are
mentioned
below.

In
general,
given
a
class
of
equations,
there
may
be
no
known
systematic
method
([170]algorithm)
that
is
guaranteed
to
work.
This
may
be
due
to
a
lack
of
mathematical
knowledge;
some
problems
were
only
solved
after
centuries
of
effort.
But
this
also
reflects
that,
in
general,
no
such
method
can
exist:
some
problems
are
known
to
be
[171]unsolvable
by
an
algorithm,
such
as
[172]Hilbert's
tenth
problem,
which
was
proved
unsolvable
in
1970.

For
several
classes
of
equations,
algorithms
have
been
found
for
solving
them,
some
of
which
have
been
implemented
and
incorporated
in
[173]computer
algebra
systems,
but
often
require
no
more
sophisticated
technology
than
pencil
and
paper.
In
some
other
cases,
[174]heuristic
methods
are
known
that
are
often
successful
but
that
are
not
guaranteed
to
lead
to
success.

Brute
force,
trial
and
error,
inspired
guess

[[175]edit]

If
the
solution
set
of
an
equation
is
restricted
to
a
finite
set
(as
is
the
case
for
equations
in
[176]modular
arithmetic,
for
example),
or
can
be
limited
to
a
finite
number
of
possibilities
(as
is
the
case
with
some
[177]Diophantine
equations),
the
solution
set
can
be
found
by
[178]brute
force,
that
is,
by
testing
each
of
the
possible
values
([179]candidate
solutions).
It
may
be
the
case,
though,
that
the
number
of
possibilities
to
be
considered,
although
finite,
is
so
huge
that
an
[180]exhaustive
search
is
not
practically
feasible;
this
is,
in
fact,
a
requirement
for
strong
[181]encryption
methods.

As
with
all
kinds
of
[182]problem
solving,
[183]trial
and
error
may
sometimes
yield
a
solution,
in
particular
where
the
form
of
the
equation,
or
its
similarity
to
another
equation
with
a
known
solution,
may
lead
to
an
"inspired
guess"
at
the
solution.
If
a
guess,
when
tested,
fails
to
be
a
solution,
consideration
of
the
way
in
which
it
fails
may
lead
to
a
modified
guess.

Elementary
algebra

[[184]edit]

Equations
involving
linear
or
simple
rational
functions
of
a
single
real-valued
unknown,
say
x,
such
as

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>8</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>7</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>4</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>35</mn>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>or</mtext>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<mn>4</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>9</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mn>3</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>4</mn>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
8x+7=4x+35\quad
{\text{or}}\quad
{\frac
{4x+9}{3x+4}}=2\,,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
8x+7=4x+35\quad
{\text{or}}\quad
{\frac
{4x+9}{3x+4}}=2\,,}

can
be
solved
using
the
methods
of
[185]elementary
algebra.

Systems
of
linear
equations

[[186]edit]

Smaller
[187]systems
of
linear
equations
can
be
solved
likewise
by
methods
of
elementary
algebra.
For
solving
larger
systems,
algorithms
are
used
that
are
based
on
[188]linear
algebra.
See
[189]Gaussian
elimination
and
[190]numerical
solution
of
linear
systems.

Polynomial
equations

[[191]edit]
Main
article:
[192]Solving
polynomial
equations
See
also:
[193]System
of
polynomial
equations

[194]Polynomial
equations
of
degree
up
to
four
can
be
solved
exactly
using
algebraic
methods,
of
which
the
[195]quadratic
formula
is
the
simplest
example.
Polynomial
equations
with
a
degree
of
five
or
higher
require
in
general
numerical
methods
(see
below)
or
special
functions
such
as
[196]Bring
radicals,
although
some
specific
cases
may
be
solvable
algebraically,
for
example

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>4</mn>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>5</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>3</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>3</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
4x^{5}-x^{3}-3=0}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
4x^{5}-x^{3}-3=0}

(by
using
the
[197]rational
root
theorem),
and

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>6</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>5</mn>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>3</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>6</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
x^{6}-5x^{3}+6=0\,,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
x^{6}-5x^{3}+6=0\,,}

(by
using
the
substitution
x
=
z^1/3
,
which
simplifies
this
to
a
[198]quadratic
equation
in
z).

Diophantine
equations

[[199]edit]

In
[200]Diophantine
equations
the
solutions
are
required
to
be
[201]integers.
In
some
cases
a
brute
force
approach
can
be
used,
as
mentioned
above.
In
some
other
cases,
in
particular
if
the
equation
is
in
one
unknown,
it
is
possible
to
solve
the
equation
for
[202]rational-valued
unknowns
(see
[203]Rational
root
theorem),
and
then
find
solutions
to
the
Diophantine
equation
by
restricting
the
solution
set
to
integer-valued
solutions.
For
example,
the
polynomial
equation

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mn>2</mn>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>5</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>5</mn>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>4</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>3</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>7</mn>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>3</mn>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
2x^{5}-5x^{4}-x^{3}-7x^{2}+2x+3=0\,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
2x^{5}-5x^{4}-x^{3}-7x^{2}+2x+3=0\,}

has
as
rational
solutions
x
=
-&#8288;1/2&#8288;
and
x
=
3,
and
so,
viewed
as
a
Diophantine
equation,
it
has
the
unique
solution
x
=
3.

In
general,
however,
Diophantine
equations
are
among
the
most
difficult
equations
to
solve.

Inverse
functions

[[204]edit]
See
also:
[205]Inverse
problem

In
the
simple
case
of
a
function
of
one
variable,
say,
h(x),
we
can
solve
an
equation
of
the
form
h(x)
=
c
for
some
constant
c
by
considering
what
is
known
as
the
[206]inverse
function
of
h.

Given
a
function
h
:
A
->
B,
the
inverse
function,
denoted
h^-1
and
defined
as
h^-1
:
B
->
A,
is
a
function
such
that

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OPEN">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">(</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mi>h</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-CLOSE">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OPEN">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">(</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-CLOSE">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
h^{-1}{\bigl
(}h(x){\bigr
)}=h{\bigl
(}h^{-1}(x){\bigr
)}=x\,.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
h^{-1}{\bigl
(}h(x){\bigr
)}=h{\bigl
(}h^{-1}(x){\bigr
)}=x\,.}

Now,
if
we
apply
the
inverse
function
to
both
sides
of
h(x)
=
c,
where
c
is
a
constant
value
in
B,
we
obtain

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtable
columnalign="right
left
right
left
right
left
right
left
right
left
right
left"
rowspacing="3pt"
columnspacing="0em
2em
0em
2em
0em
2em
0em
2em
0em
2em
0em"
displaystyle="true">
<mtr>
<mtd>
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OPEN">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">(</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
<mi>h</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-CLOSE">
<mo
maxsize="1.2em"
minsize="1.2em">)</mo>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</mtd>
<mtd>
<mi></mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mtd>
</mtr>
<mtr>
<mtd>
<mi>x</mi>
</mtd>
<mtd>
<mi></mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mtd>
</mtr>
</mtable>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\begin{aligned}h^{-1}{\bigl
(}h(x){\bigr
)}&=h^{-1}(c)\\x&=h^{-1}(c)\\\end{aligned}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\begin{aligned}h^{-1}{\bigl
(}h(x){\bigr
)}&=h^{-1}(c)\\x&=h^{-1}(c)\\\end{aligned}}}

and
we
have
found
the
solution
to
the
equation.
However,
depending
on
the
function,
the
inverse
may
be
difficult
to
be
defined,
or
may
not
be
a
function
on
all
of
the
set
B
(only
on
some
subset),
and
have
many
values
at
some
point.

If
just
one
solution
will
do,
instead
of
the
full
solution
set,
it
is
actually
sufficient
if
only
the
functional
identity

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<msup>
<mi>h</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
h\left(h^{-1}(x)\right)=x}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
h\left(h^{-1}(x)\right)=x}

holds.
For
example,
the
[207]projection
p[1]
:
R^2
->
R
defined
by
p[1](x,
y)
=
x
has
no
post-inverse,
but
it
has
a
pre-inverse
p^-1
[1]
defined
by
p^-1
[1](x)
=
(x,
0).
Indeed,
the
equation
p[1](x,
y)
=
c
is
solved
by

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mi>y</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<msubsup>
<mi>p</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
</msubsup>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>=</mo>
<mo
stretchy="false">(</mo>
<mi>c</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo
stretchy="false">)</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
(x,y)=\pi
_{1}^{-1}(c)=(c,0).}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
(x,y)=\pi
_{1}^{-1}(c)=(c,0).}

Examples
of
inverse
functions
include
the
[208]nth
root
(inverse
of
x^n);
the
[209]logarithm
(inverse
of
a^x);
the
[210]inverse
trigonometric
functions;
and
[211]Lambert's
W
function
(inverse
of
xe^x).

Factorization

[[212]edit]

If
the
left-hand
side
expression
of
an
equation
P
=
0
can
be
[213]factorized
as
P
=
QR,
the
solution
set
of
the
original
solution
consists
of
the
union
of
the
solution
sets
of
the
two
equations
Q
=
0
and
R
=
0.
For
example,
the
equation

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>tan</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>cot</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\tan
x+\cot
x=2}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\tan
x+\cot
x=2}

can
be
rewritten,
using
the
identity
tan
x
cot
x
=
1
as

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<mrow>
<msup>
<mi>tan</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mi>tan</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>+</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mrow>
<mi>tan</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\tan
^{2}x-2\tan
x+1}{\tan
x}}=0,}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\tan
^{2}x-2\tan
x+1}{\tan
x}}=0,}

which
can
be
factorized
into

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mfrac>
<msup>
<mrow>
<mo>(</mo>
<mrow>
<mi>tan</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>-</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
</mrow>
<mo>)</mo>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>2</mn>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mrow>
<mi>tan</mi>
<mo>&#x2061;</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
</mrow>
</mfrac>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0.</mn>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\left(\tan
x-1\right)^{2}}{\tan
x}}=0.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\frac
{\left(\tan
x-1\right)^{2}}{\tan
x}}=0.}

The
solutions
are
thus
the
solutions
of
the
equation
tan
x
=
1,
and
are
thus
the
set

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="false"
scriptlevel="0">
<mfrac>
<mi>p</mi>
<mn>4</mn>
</mfrac>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>k</mi>
<mi>p</mi>
<mo>,</mo>
<mspace
width="1em"
/>
<mi>k</mi>
<mo>=</mo>
<mn>0</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>±</mo>
<mn>1</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>±</mo>
<mn>2</mn>
<mo>,</mo>
<mo>...</mo>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
x={\tfrac
{\pi
}{4}}+k\pi
,\quad
k=0,\pm
1,\pm
2,\ldots
.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
x={\tfrac
{\pi
}{4}}+k\pi
,\quad
k=0,\pm
1,\pm
2,\ldots
.}

Numerical
methods

[[214]edit]

With
more
complicated
equations
in
real
or
[215]complex
numbers,
simple
methods
to
solve
equations
can
fail.
Often,
[216]root-finding
algorithms
like
the
[217]Newton-Raphson
method
can
be
used
to
find
a
numerical
solution
to
an
equation,
which,
for
some
applications,
can
be
entirely
sufficient
to
solve
some
problem.
There
are
also
[218]numerical
methods
for
systems
of
linear
equations.

Matrix
equations

[[219]edit]

Equations
involving
[220]matrices
and
[221]vectors
of
[222]real
numbers
can
often
be
solved
by
using
methods
from
[223]linear
algebra.

Differential
equations

[[224]edit]

There
is
a
vast
body
of
methods
for
solving
various
kinds
of
[225]differential
equations,
both
[226]numerically
and
[227]analytically.
A
particular
class
of
problem
that
can
be
considered
to
belong
here
is
[228]integration,
and
the
analytic
methods
for
solving
this
kind
of
problems
are
now
called
[229]symbolic
integration.^[[230]citation
needed]
Solutions
of
differential
equations
can
be
[231]implicit
or
explicit.^[232][1]

See
also

[[233]edit]
*
[234]Extraneous
and
missing
solutions
*
[235]Simultaneous
equations
*
[236]Equating
coefficients
*
[237]Solving
the
geodesic
equations
*
[238]Unification
(computer
science)
--
solving
equations
involving
symbolic
expressions

*
[82]Wikidata
item

Appearance
(BUTTON)
move
to
sidebar
(BUTTON)
hide
From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Linux
standard
for
directory
structure

CAPTION:
Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard

Abbreviation
FHS
Status
Published
Year
started
14
February
1994;
30
years
ago
(1994-02-14)
Latest
version
3.0
3
June
2015;
9
years
ago
(2015-06-03)
Organization
[83]Linux
Foundation
Domain
[84]Directory
structure
Website
[85]Official
website
[86]Official
website
(Historical)

The
Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard
(FHS)
is
a
reference
describing
the
conventions
used
for
the
layout
of
[87]Unix-like
systems.
It
has
been
made
popular
by
its
use
in
[88]Linux
distributions,
but
it
is
used
by
other
Unix-like
systems
as
well.^[89][1]
It
is
maintained
by
the
[90]Linux
Foundation.
The
latest
version
is
3.0,
released
on
3
June
2015.^[91][2]

Directory
structure

[[92]edit]
[93][300px-Ubuntu_Filesystem_Hierarchy.png]
Typical
[94]Ubuntu
filesystem
hierarchy

In
the
FHS,
all
files
and
[95]directories
appear
under
the
[96]root
directory
/,
even
if
they
are
stored
on
different
physical
or
virtual
devices.
Some
of
these
directories
only
exist
in
a
particular
system
if
certain
subsystems,
such
as
the
[97]X
Window
System,
are
installed.

Most
of
these
directories
exist
in
all
[98]Unix-like
operating
systems
and
are
generally
used
in
much
the
same
way;
however,
the
descriptions
here
are
those
used
specifically
for
the
FHS
and
are
not
considered
authoritative
for
platforms
other
than
Linux.
Directory
Description
/
Primary
hierarchy
root
and
[99]root
directory
of
the
entire
file
system
hierarchy.
/bin
Essential
command
[100]binaries
that
need
to
be
available
in
[101]single-user
mode,
including
to
bring
up
the
system
or
repair
it,^[102][3]
for
all
users
(e.g.,
[103]cat,
[104]ls,
[105]cp).
[106]/boot
[107]Boot
loader
files
(e.g.,
[108]kernels,
[109]initrd).
[110]/dev
[111]Device
files
(e.g.,
[112]/dev/null,
/dev/disk0,
/dev/sda1,
/dev/tty,
[113]/dev/random).
/etc
Host-specific
system-wide
[114]configuration
files.

There
has
been
controversy
over
the
meaning
of
the
name
itself.
In
early
versions
of
the
UNIX
Implementation
Document
from
Bell
Labs,
/etc
is
referred
to
as
the
[115]etcetera
directory,^[116][4]
as
this
directory
historically
held
everything
that
did
not
belong
elsewhere
(however,
the
FHS
restricts
/etc
to
static
configuration
files
and
may
not
contain
binaries).^[117][5]
Since
the
publication
of
early
documentation,
the
directory
name
has
been
re-explained
in
various
ways.
Recent
interpretations
include
[118]backronyms
such
as
"Editable
Text
Configuration"
or
"Extended
Tool
Chest".^[119][6]
/etc/opt
Configuration
files
for
add-on
packages
stored
in
/opt.
/etc/sgml
Configuration
files,
such
as
catalogs,
for
software
that
processes
[120]SGML.
/etc/X11
Configuration
files
for
the
[121]X
Window
System,
version
11.
/etc/xml
Configuration
files,
such
as
catalogs,
for
software
that
processes
[122]XML.
/home
Users'
[123]home
directories,
containing
saved
files,
personal
settings,
etc.
/lib
[124]Libraries
essential
for
the
[125]binaries
in
/bin
and
/sbin.
/lib<qual>
Alternate
format
essential
libraries.
These
are
typically
used
on
systems
that
support
more
than
one
executable
code
format,
such
as
systems
supporting
[126]32-bit
and
[127]64-bit
versions
of
an
[128]instruction
set.
Such
directories
are
optional,
but
if
they
exist,
they
have
some
requirements.
/media
Mount
points
for
[129]removable
media
such
as
[130]CD-ROMs
(appeared
in
FHS-2.3
in
2004).
/mnt
Temporarily
[131]mounted
filesystems.
/opt
Add-on
[132]application
software
[133]packages.^[134][7]
[135]/proc
Virtual
[136]filesystem
providing
[137]process
and
[138]kernel
information
as
files.
In
Linux,
corresponds
to
a
[139]procfs
mount.
Generally,
automatically
generated
and
populated
by
the
system,
on
the
fly.
/root
[140]Home
directory
for
the
[141]root
user.
/run
Run-time
variable
data:
Information
about
the
running
system
since
last
boot,
e.g.,
currently
logged-in
users
and
running
[142]daemons.
Files
under
this
directory
must
be
either
removed
or
truncated
at
the
beginning
of
the
boot
process,
but
this
is
not
necessary
on
systems
that
provide
this
directory
as
a
[143]temporary
filesystem
([144]tmpfs)
(appeared
in
FHS-3.0
in
2015).
/sbin
Essential
system
binaries
(e.g.,
[145]fsck,
[146]init,
[147]route).
/srv
Site-specific
data
served
by
this
system,
such
as
data
and
scripts
for
web
servers,
data
offered
by
[148]FTP
servers,
and
repositories
for
[149]version
control
systems
(appeared
in
FHS-2.3
in
2004).
/sys
Contains
information
about
devices,
drivers,
and
some
kernel
features.^[150][8]
/tmp
[151]Directory
for
temporary
files
(see
also
/var/tmp).
Often
not
preserved
between
system
reboots
and
may
be
severely
size-restricted.
/usr
Secondary
hierarchy
for
read-only
user
data;
contains
the
majority
of
([152]multi-)user
utilities
and
applications.
Should
be
shareable
and
read-only.^[153][9]^[154][10]
/usr/bin
Non-essential
command
[155]binaries
(not
needed
in
[156]single-user
mode);
for
all
users.
/usr/include
Standard
[157]include
files.
/usr/lib
[158]Libraries
for
the
[159]binaries
in
/usr/bin
and
/usr/sbin.
/usr/libexec
Binaries
run
by
other
programs
that
are
not
intended
to
be
executed
directly
by
users
or
shell
scripts
(optional).
/usr/lib<qual>
Alternative-format
libraries
(e.g.,
/usr/lib32
for
32-bit
libraries
on
a
64-bit
machine
(optional)).
/usr/local
Tertiary
hierarchy
for
local
data,
specific
to
this
host.
Typically
has
further
subdirectories
(e.g.,
bin,
lib,
share).^[160][NB
1]
/usr/sbin
Non-essential
system
binaries
(e.g.,
[161]daemons
for
various
[162]network
services).
/usr/share
Architecture-independent
(shared)
data.
/usr/src
[163]Source
code
(e.g.,
the
kernel
source
code
with
its
header
files).
/usr/X11R6
[164]X
Window
System,
Version
11,
Release
6
(up
to
FHS-2.3,
optional).
/var
Variable
files:
files
whose
content
is
expected
to
continually
change
during
normal
operation
of
the
system,
such
as
logs,
spool
files,
and
temporary
e-mail
files.
/var/cache
Application
cache
data.
Such
data
are
locally
generated
as
a
result
of
time-consuming
I/O
or
calculation.
The
application
must
be
able
to
regenerate
or
restore
the
data.
The
cached
files
can
be
deleted
without
loss
of
data.
/var/lib
State
information.
Persistent
data
modified
by
programs
as
they
run
(e.g.,
databases,
packaging
system
metadata,
etc.).
/var/lock
Lock
files.
Files
keeping
track
of
resources
currently
in
use.
/var/log
Log
files.
Various
logs.
/var/mail
Mailbox
files.
In
some
distributions,
these
files
may
be
located
in
the
deprecated
/var/spool/mail.
/var/opt
Variable
data
from
add-on
packages
that
are
stored
in
/opt.
/var/run
Run-time
variable
data.
This
directory
contains
system
information
data
describing
the
system
since
it
was
booted.^[165][11]

In
FHS
3.0,
/var/run
is
replaced
by
/run;
a
system
should
either
continue
to
provide
a
/var/run
directory
or
provide
a
symbolic
link
from
/var/run
to
/run
for
backwards
compatibility.^[166][12]
/var/spool
[167]Spool
for
tasks
waiting
to
be
processed
(e.g.,
print
queues
and
outgoing
mail
queue).
/var/spool/mail
[168]Deprecated
location
for
users'
mailboxes.^[169][13]
/var/tmp
Temporary
files
to
be
preserved
between
reboots.

FHS
compliance

[[170]edit]

Most
[171]Linux
distributions
follow
the
Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard
and
declare
it
their
own
policy
to
maintain
FHS
compliance.^[172][14]^[173][15]^[174][16]^[175][17]
[176]GoboLinux^[177][18]
and
[178]NixOS^[179][19]
provide
examples
of
intentionally
non-compliant
filesystem
implementations.

Some
distributions
generally
follow
the
standard
but
deviate
from
it
in
some
areas.
The
FHS
is
a
"trailing
standard",
and
so
documents
common
practices
at
a
point
in
time.
Of
course,
times
change,
and
distribution
goals
and
needs
call
for
experimentation.
Some
common
deviations
include:
*
Modern
Linux
distributions
include
a
/sys
directory
as
a
[180]virtual
filesystem
([181]sysfs,
comparable
to
/proc,
which
is
a
[182]procfs),
which
stores
and
allows
modification
of
the
devices
connected
to
the
system,^[183][20]
whereas
many
traditional
[184]Unix-like
operating
systems
use
/sys
as
a
[185]symbolic
link
to
the
[186]kernel
source
tree.^[187][21]
*
Many
modern
Unix-like
systems
(such
as
[188]FreeBSD
and
[189]OpenBSD)
via
their
[190]ports
systems
install
third-party
packages
into
/usr/local,
while
keeping
code
considered
part
of
the
operating
system
in
/usr.
*
Some
Linux
distributions
no
longer
differentiate
between
/lib
and
/usr/lib
and
have
/lib
symlinked
to
/usr/lib.^[191][22]
*
Some
Linux
distributions
no
longer
differentiate
between
/bin
and
/usr/bin
and
between
/sbin
and
/usr/sbin.
They
may
symlink
/bin
to
/usr/bin
and
/sbin
to
/usr/sbin.
Other
distributions
choose
to
consolidate
all
four,
symlinking
them
to
/usr/bin.^[192][23]

Modern
Linux
distributions
include
a
/run
directory
as
a
[193]temporary
filesystem
([194]tmpfs),
which
stores
volatile
runtime
data,
following
the
FHS
version
3.0.
According
to
the
FHS
version
2.3,
such
data
were
stored
in
/var/run,
but
this
was
a
problem
in
some
cases
because
this
directory
is
not
always
available
at
early
boot.
As
a
result,
these
programs
have
had
to
resort
to
trickery,
such
as
using
/dev/.udev,
/dev/.mdadm,
/dev/.systemd
or
/dev/.mount
directories,
even
though
the
device
directory
is
not
intended
for
such
data.^[195][24]
Among
other
advantages,
this
makes
the
system
easier
to
use
normally
with
the
root
filesystem
mounted
read-only.
For
example,
below
are
the
changes
[196]Debian
made
in
its
2013
Wheezy
release:^[197][25]
*
/dev/.*
->
/run/*
*
/dev/shm
->
/run/shm
*
/dev/shm/*
->
/run/*
*
/etc/*
(writeable
files)
->
/run/*
*
/lib/init/rw
->
/run
*
/var/lock
->
/run/lock
*
/var/run
->
/run
*
/tmp
->
/run/tmp

History

[[198]edit]

The
name
of
usr

[[199]edit]

/usr
originally
stood
for
"user".^[200][26]
This
was
an
artifact
of
early
Unix
programming.
Specifically,
when
[201]Ken
Thompson
and
[202]Dennis
Ritchie
were
migrating
Unix
to
a
PDP-11,
the
contents
of
the
/bin
and
/lib
directories,
which
were
to
be
the
first
directories
mounted
on
startup
and
to
contain
all
essentials
for
the
OS
to
function,
became
too
large
to
fit
on
an
[203]RK05
disk
drive.
So
they
put
some
of
those
files
on
a
second
RK05,
making
sure
that
the
first
drive
contained
everything
required
for
loading
the
second
one.
The
rest
of
the
files
were
put
into
the
/usr
directory.^[204][27]
When
they
got
a
third
drive,
users'
files
were
moved
to
a
new
directory
named
/home.^[205][28]

FHS
was
created
as
the
FSSTND
(short
for
"Filesystem
Standard"^[206][29]),
largely
based
on
similar
standards
for
other
[207]Unix-like
operating
systems.
Notable
examples
are
these:
the
hier(7)
description
of
file
system
layout,^[208][30]
which
has
existed
since
the
release
of
[209]Version
7
Unix
(in
1979);^[210][31]
the
[211]SunOS
filesystem(7)^[212][32]
and
its
successor,
the
[213]Solaris
filesystem(7).^[214][33]^[215][34]

Release
history

[[216]edit]
Version
Release
date
Notes
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
1.0
1994-02-14
FSSTND^[217][35]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
1.1
1994-10-09
FSSTND^[218][36]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
1.2
1995-03-28
FSSTND^[219][37]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
2.0
1997-10-26
FHS
2.0
is
the
direct
successor
for
FSSTND
1.2.
Name
of
the
standard
was
changed
to
Filesystem
Hierarchy
Standard.^[220][38]^[221][39]^[222][40]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
2.1
2000-04-12
FHS^[223][41]^[224][42]^[225][43]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
2.2
2001-05-23
FHS^[226][44]
Old
version,
no
longer
maintained:
2.3
2004-01-29
FHS^[227][45]
Current
stable
version:
3.0
2015-05-18
FHS^[228][46]
Legend:
Old
version
Old
version,
still
maintained
Latest
version
Latest
preview
version
Future
release

See
also

[[229]edit]
*
[230]Hierarchical
file
system
*
[231]Unix
directory
structure
*
[232]XDG
Base
Directory
Specification

Notes

[[233]edit]
1.
[234]^
Historically
and
strictly
according
to
the
standard,
/usr/local
is
for
data
that
must
be
stored
on
the
local
host
(as
opposed
to
/usr,
which
may
be
mounted
across
a
network).
Most
of
the
time
/usr/local
is
used
for
installing
software/data
that
are
not
part
of
the
standard
operating
system
distribution
(in
such
case,
/usr
would
only
contain
software/data
that
are
part
of
the
standard
operating
system
distribution).
It
is
possible
that
the
FHS
standard
may
in
the
future
be
changed
to
reflect
this
de
facto
convention.

From
Wikipedia,
the
free
encyclopedia
Arithmetic
operation,
inverse
of
nth
power
This
article
is
about
nth-roots
of
real
and
complex
numbers.
For
other
uses,
see
[143]Root
(disambiguation)
§
Mathematics.

This
article
needs
additional
citations
for
[144]verification.
Please
help
[145]improve
this
article
by
[146]adding
citations
to
reliable
sources.
Unsourced
material
may
be
challenged
and
removed.
Find
sources:
[147]"Nth
root"
-
[148]news
·
[149]newspapers
·
[150]books
·
[151]scholar
·
[152]JSTOR
(October
2022)
([153]Learn
how
and
when
to
remove
this
message)

In
[154]mathematics,
an
nth
root
of
a
[155]number
x
is
a
number
r
(the
root)
which,
when
[156]raised
to
the
power
of
the
[157]positive
integer
n,
yields
x:
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<msup>
<mi>r</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>=</mo>
<munder>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-OP
MJX-fixedlimits">
<munder>
<mrow>
<mi>r</mi>
<mo>×</mo>
<mi>r</mi>
<mo>×</mo>
<mo>.3</mo>
<mo>×</mo>
<mi>r</mi>
</mrow>
<mo>&#x23DF;</mo>
</munder>
</mrow>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>
factors</mtext>
</mrow>
</mrow>
</munder>
<mo>=</mo>
<mi>x</mi>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
r^{n}=\underbrace
{r\times
r\times
\dotsb
\times
r}
_{n{\text{
factors}}}=x.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
r^{n}=\underbrace
{r\times
r\times
\dotsb
\times
r}
_{n{\text{
factors}}}=x.}

The
integer
n
is
called
the
index
or
degree,
and
the
number
x
of
which
the
root
is
taken
is
the
radicand.
A
root
of
degree
2
is
called
a
[158]square
root
and
a
root
of
degree
3,
a
[159]cube
root.
Roots
of
higher
degree
are
referred
by
using
[160]ordinal
numbers,
as
in
fourth
root,
twentieth
root,
etc.
The
computation
of
an
nth
root
is
a
root
extraction.

For
example,
3
is
a
square
root
of
9,
since
3^2
=
9,
and
-3
is
also
a
square
root
of
9,
since
(-3)^2
=
9.

The
nth
root
of
x
is
written
as
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mroot>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</mroot>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}
using
the
[161]radical
symbol
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mphantom>
<mi>x</mi>
</mphantom>
</mrow>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{\phantom
{x}}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{\phantom
{x}}}}
.
The
square
root
is
usually
written
without
the
n
as
just
&#8288;
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mi>x</mi>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{x}}}
&#8288;.
Taking
the
nth
root
of
a
number
is
the
[162]inverse
operation
of
[163]exponentiation,^[164][1]
and
can
be
written
as
a
[165]fractional
exponent:

[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mroot>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</mroot>
</mrow>
<mo>=</mo>
<msup>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mn>1</mn>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mo>/</mo>
</mrow>
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</msup>
<mo>.</mo>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}=x^{1/n}.}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}=x^{1/n}.}

For
a
positive
real
number
x,
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mi>x</mi>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt
{x}}}
denotes
the
positive
square
root
of
x
and
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mroot>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</mroot>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}
denotes
the
positive
real
nth
root.
A
negative
real
number
-x
has
no
real-valued
square
roots,
but
when
x
is
treated
as
a
complex
number
it
has
two
[166]imaginary
square
roots,
&#8288;
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo>+</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mi>x</mi>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
+i{\sqrt
{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
+i{\sqrt
{x}}}
&#8288;
and
&#8288;
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mo>-</mo>
<mi>i</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<msqrt>
<mi>x</mi>
</msqrt>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
-i{\sqrt
{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
-i{\sqrt
{x}}}
&#8288;,
where
i
is
the
[167]imaginary
unit.

In
general,
any
non-zero
[168]complex
number
has
n
distinct
complex-valued
nth
roots,
equally
distributed
around
a
complex
circle
of
constant
[169]absolute
value.
(The
nth
root
of
0
is
zero
with
[170]multiplicity
n,
and
this
circle
degenerates
to
a
point.)
Extracting
the
nth
roots
of
a
complex
number
x
can
thus
be
taken
to
be
a
[171]multivalued
function.
By
convention
the
[172]principal
value
of
this
function,
called
the
principal
root
and
denoted
&#8288;
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mroot>
<mi>x</mi>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mi>n</mi>
</mrow>
</mroot>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
{\sqrt[{n}]{x}}}
&#8288;,
is
taken
to
be
the
nth
root
with
the
greatest
real
part
and
in
the
special
case
when
x
is
a
negative
real
number,
the
one
with
a
positive
[173]imaginary
part.
The
principal
root
of
a
positive
real
number
is
thus
also
a
positive
real
number.
As
a
[174]function,
the
principal
root
is
[175]continuous
in
the
whole
[176]complex
plane,
except
along
the
negative
real
axis.

An
unresolved
root,
especially
one
using
the
radical
symbol,
is
sometimes
referred
to
as
a
surd^[177][2]
or
a
radical.^[178][3]
Any
expression
containing
a
radical,
whether
it
is
a
square
root,
a
cube
root,
or
a
higher
root,
is
called
a
radical
expression,
and
if
it
contains
no
[179]transcendental
functions
or
[180]transcendental
numbers
it
is
called
an
[181]algebraic
expression.
[182]Arithmetic
operations
*
[183]v
*
[184]t
*
[185]e

[186]Addition
(+)
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mstyle
displaystyle="false"
scriptlevel="1">

stretchy="true"

<mrow

<mtr>

</mtr>
<mtr>
<mtd>

<mspace

/>
<mrow

</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mtd>
</mtr>
<mtr>
<mtd>
<mstyle

<mrow

</mrow>
<mspace

/>

<mspace

<mrow

<mtext>addend</mtext>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mtd>
</mtr>
</mtable>
</mrow>
<mo>}</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mo>=</mo>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
</mstyle>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
\left.{\begin{matrix}\scriptstyle
{\text{term}}\,+\,{\text{term}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{summand}}\,+\,{\text{summand}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{addend}}\,+\,{\text{addend}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{augend}}\,+\,{\text{addend}}\end{matrix}}\right\}\,=\,}</annotat
ion>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
\left.{\begin{matrix}\scriptstyle
{\text{term}}\,+\,{\text{term}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{summand}}\,+\,{\text{summand}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{addend}}\,+\,{\text{addend}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{augend}}\,+\,{\text{addend}}\end{matrix}}\right\}\,=\,}
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">
<mstyle
displaystyle="false"
scriptlevel="1">
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>sum</mtext>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
{\text{sum}}}</annotation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
{\text{sum}}}
[187]Subtraction
(-)
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle

<mstyle

scriptlevel="1">

<mrow

</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mtd>
</mtr>
<mtr>
<mtd>
<mstyle

scriptlevel="1">
<mrow

<mtext>minuend</mtext>
</mrow>
<mspace

/>
<mo>-</mo>
<mspace

<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mtext>subtrahend</mtext>
</mrow>
</mstyle>
</mtd>
</mtr>
</mtable>
</mrow>
<mo>}</mo>
</mrow>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
<mo>=</mo>
<mspace
width="thinmathspace"
/>
</mstyle>
</mstyle>
</mrow>
<annotation
encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
\left.{\begin{matrix}\scriptstyle
{\text{term}}\,-\,{\text{term}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{minuend}}\,-\,{\text{subtrahend}}\end{matrix}}\right\}\,=\,}</an
notation>
</semantics>
:MATH]
{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
\left.{\begin{matrix}\scriptstyle
{\text{term}}\,-\,{\text{term}}\\\scriptstyle
{\text{minuend}}\,-\,{\text{subtrahend}}\end{matrix}}\right\}\,=\,}

[192]Exponentiation
(^)
[MATH:

{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
\left.{\begin{matrix}\scriptstyle

[MATH:

{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
{\text{power}}}
nth
root
(
SQRT
)
[MATH:
<semantics>
<mrow
class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
<mstyle
displaystyle="true"
scriptlevel="0">

class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">

encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
{\sqrt[{\text{degree}}]{\scriptstyle
{\text{radicand}}}}\,=\,}</annotation>

{\displaystyle
\scriptstyle
{\sqrt[{\text{degree}}]{\scriptstyle
{\text{radicand}}}}\,=\,}

<semantics>

class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
